[10-Dec-23 06:38 PM] Deleted User#0000
Antares Initiative: 10% bonus on electronics
Castillo-Ito Mercantile: 10% bonus on manufacturing
Insitor Cooperative: 6% bonus on agriculture, 4% on food industries
NEO Charter Exploration: 4% bonus on metallurgy, 6% on construction
No faction: 4% bonus each on chemistry, fuel refining and resource extraction

HMS Pandora was a 24-gun Porcupine-class sixth-rate post ship of the Royal Navy launched in May 1779. The vessel is best known for its role in hunting down the Bounty mutineers in 1790, which remains one of the best-known stories in the history of seafaring. [31-Jan-24 12:19 PM] avalock#0000
ahhhhhhh


[31-Jan-24 12:19 PM] shagie#0000
FTL speed is a function of ship volume.  It gets _worse_ as the ship gets bigger.  For fuel and speed (SCB < MCB = WCB < LCB < VCB) - lower is better.
STL speed is related to acceleration and engine ... but avoid upgrading the engine on a starter ship since that's a $$$ piece and the standard isn't bad.


[31-Jan-24 12:20 PM] avalock#0000
yeah i just want to move more ALO


[31-Jan-24 12:20 PM] shagie#0000
You want a WCB upgrade for a starter ship.

{Reactions}
üëÜ 

[31-Jan-24 12:20 PM] avalock#0000
:woopsNote1:


[31-Jan-24 12:21 PM] shagie#0000
https://discord.com/channels/855488309802172469/1202257500213366804


[31-Jan-24 12:22 PM] shagie#0000
Key things with WCB upgrade for starter - it has the minimum replacement cost.  The bridge and crew quarters stay the same... and that's another $$$ part of ugprade.  FTL emitters are a minor change, but not too bad (FTL emitter upgrade for going to a LCB gets more $$$ ... and it needs a larger CQ which is again more $$$)


[31-Jan-24 12:22 PM] avalock#0000
i unfortunately dont have the money to upgrade yet but maybe soon :hehe:


[31-Jan-24 12:23 PM] shagie#0000
The reason that you want a WCB rather than MCB for ALO and AL is that they are heavier than they are massive.


[31-Jan-24 12:23 PM] avalock#0000
yeee that makes sense


[31-Jan-24 12:25 PM] shagie#0000
You can carry 1000 AL in a WCB (2.7t / 1m3) with m3 being the limit.  You can only carry 740 in a LCB (even though its 'bigger' for the m3 dimension, that one gets hit with a limit on the t because its more than 2).


[31-Jan-24 12:26 PM] shagie#0000
You'll see similar things with hauling C (2.25 t / 1m)  and even rations (0.21 t/ 0.1 m3) where the WCB is the better choice for low tier massive stuff.


[31-Jan-24 12:27 PM] shagie#0000
I once looked into the logistics of hauling TCO... yea.  That one got silly. (bot spam for some how much can you fit for that)

[03-Feb-24 09:28 AM] Deleted User#0000

[03-Feb-24 09:32 AM] shagie#0000
It could.  It was designed for a particular style of game play and has been trying to get into the real world business use cases and community hosting... but with awkward funding models (and layoffs)  Slack has been doing anti-nonpaying user things for a while but they've got a solid business model, but if you're not paying some of its choices grate on the user and its _really_ intended for corporate structures.  Perrsonally, I like Zulip because its slack like and self hostable ... but there is strong inertia to discord because you can do easy cross discord links.

[07-Mar-24 01:52 PM] Deleted User#0000
Office is more formal than communal.


[07-Mar-24 01:52 PM] Deleted User#0000
Associates are just people within the Discord.


[07-Mar-24 01:52 PM] Deleted User#0000
Members are those who have actually been involved.


[07-Mar-24 01:52 PM] Deleted User#0000
Bulletin boards were meant to be used for either important notices or for information.

[26-Mar-24 09:46 AM] talryk#0000
Ooooh, how‚Äôs that gonna work? :aerysWut:


[26-Mar-24 10:14 AM] Deleted User#0000
Passive thing where through select regular LM or ADI people who ship will have their transports insured, so that should one party or the other fail to deliver, ADI will cover the costs.


[26-Mar-24 10:15 AM] Deleted User#0000
It'll work both ways so neither ends up getting screwed over, but the main benefit is for the people who regularly use the LM to ship contracts so that if a new player picks up their contract and quit, they don't end up losing out on their capital.


[26-Mar-24 10:15 AM] Deleted User#0000
This won't be too useful I suspect nor will there be much use often, but in the event something does occur, it'll be there.


[26-Mar-24 10:16 AM] Deleted User#0000
And it'll pave the way for our eventual shipping program of itself, in which I'd like to get regular shipments done specifically from the big planets like ANT to Deimos, Harmonia, Heph, Phobos, Nike, etc. and then expand it to the further out planets as we can.

[27-Mar-24 09:23 AM] talryk#0000
Molp was kind enough to direct me to a JS library, of which they use a Java port, to calculate position of celestial bodies. That reduces a ton of complexity in reverse-engineering this entire issue: https://github.com/benelsen/orb

{Embed}
https://github.com/benelsen/orb
GitHub - benelsen/orb: orb is a library for simple orbital mechanics
orb is a library for simple orbital mechanics. Contribute to benelsen/orb development by creating an account on GitHub.

a more general question - flying/fuel wise is there a way to get 'optimal' for longest time i just sent ships at the 'default' but it seems like if you tinker with the bars you can get them to go lower and still be faster in some situations


[22-Apr-24 11:55 AM] evany.#0000
is there a way to reliably select the cheapest/fastest (optimal) fuel levels?


[22-Apr-24 12:08 PM] sidepipe#0000
not that I know of, you just have to click around a bit until you get the shorter route


[22-Apr-24 01:10 PM] jvaler#0000
there's a known bug where theres 2 separate flight paths your ship can take, and clicking anywhere on the fuel bars will randomize between the two. (randomized but not always 50/50 for unknown reasons)

one of the paths is most often strictly superior to the other, so it's always good to compare both.
in my experience this superiority doesn't exist in STL-only flights

[11-May-24 03:05 PM] realharvey#0000

[11-May-24 03:06 PM] realharvey#0000

[11-May-24 03:06 PM] realharvey#0000
and everything of that endmaterial that is produced is split between everyone

https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/1183249178156089374/1240455132769161286/image.png?ex=6814b51e&is=6813639e&hm=80e7f49ec77982bee5c801805304f53ec639ccf6282925b2123da6fef845de19&


[15-May-24 07:06 PM] avalock#0000
you wanna know how candles work?


[15-May-24 07:07 PM] darkgineer#0000
*They burn, ain't they?*


[15-May-24 07:10 PM] avalock#0000
The green is buying, red is selling, 

Low - Lowest point something was bought or sold
Open - Where the price was at the start of that segment
Close - The price was at the close of the segment
High - Highest point something was bought or sold

the bottom is for volume, it's general buying or selling volume

{Attachments}
https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/1183249178156089374/1240456237221543996/NAD_BlogInfographic_Candlesticks_Anatomy.png?ex=6814b625&is=681364a5&hm=fdb18c2a6506c37bbfdd2ec4bda2c832865685eba1cb051b1ab18a8eb8e78263&


[15-May-24 07:10 PM] avalock#0000
SMA (10) is the simple moving average across the last 10 segments


[15-May-24 07:12 PM] avalock#0000
Oh the segment for the candlesticks are like uhhh


[15-May-24 07:12 PM] avalock#0000
what you have on the top right


[15-May-24 07:12 PM] avalock#0000
so each candle stick is 4 hours worth of trading


[15-May-24 07:13 PM] darkgineer#0000
Uh-huh. If green is buying, what does four consecutive green candles on my screenshot mean? In like generic language.


[15-May-24 07:14 PM] avalock#0000
the opens were higher than the closes :hehe:


[15-May-24 07:17 PM] darkgineer#0000
And what does these thin lines mead?

{Attachments}
https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/1183249178156089374/1240458046031925349/image.png?ex=6814b7d4&is=68136654&hm=40d94992e4ae823647f7ffad3221480c5f8526a00aa78791df088027ec27e206&


[15-May-24 07:17 PM] avalock#0000
those are the high and low lines, so where the buying and selling was the like highest in that trade period

[31-May-24 12:36 PM] jvaler#0000
@evany. me and @sidepipe are discussing ways to help early-midgame players get their hands on their first WCB. we'd like to know what was your experience with schaitr like? specifically the wait time


[31-May-24 12:41 PM] evany.#0000
timely !

I requested may 14
he acknowledged may 14
he told me 9days
he said may 24 ready for pickup (10 days)

so fairly close


[31-May-24 12:42 PM] jvaler#0000
oh wow okay, way quicker than i thought


[31-May-24 12:42 PM] jvaler#0000
and faster than rise, given their current backlog...


[31-May-24 12:42 PM] jvaler#0000
hmm


[31-May-24 12:42 PM] jvaler#0000
ty


[31-May-24 12:44 PM] evany.#0000
one thing i'd add for people in that position is get your SSC and LHP over to heph FIRST.


[31-May-24 12:44 PM] evany.#0000
you cannot fit the WCB parts + that in a single starter ship


[31-May-24 12:45 PM] evany.#0000
in my case i ended up having to bring a ship back to pick up the other parts to deliver them to shipyard and then i was able to upgrade


[31-May-24 12:45 PM] evany.#0000
so if there are others getting their first WCB - i'd encourage you to deliver the other parts first on your trip back from moria so your not waiting the extra ~16 hours


[31-May-24 12:52 PM] igfloz#0000
@evany.  what was the cost for parts  + ship build if you can give an indications of a goal wallet required


[31-May-24 12:54 PM] evany.#0000
he does deals for 650k for WCB kit

> Standard (WCB+LFE @ 470k) - these are the basic parts required to upgrade to a WCB-capable ship
> Enhanced (WCB+LFE+MSL+LFL @ 650k) - the added fuel tanks provide longer range for your ship
> 
> https://discord.com/channels/855488309802172469/1202257500213366804/1202257500213366804


[31-May-24 12:57 PM] evany.#0000
the common advice and something i found form tinkering is to install an LHP for a 10% faster ship too.

so total components you will need to source by yourself: (these are the components you should pre-stage on heph too)
LHP 68
SSC 32

the components provided are the: (these are provided in his kit)
LFE 1
LFL 1
MSL 1
WCB 1

[01-Jun-24 06:45 PM] cptcoleslaw#0000
I just have an irrational distaste for flying empty anywhere, so the to/from CX doesn't make me happy üòÜ Also, since KAWA mostly trades internally instead of using CX, most of the hubs where I buy things are actually just planets. [01-Jun-24 06:47 PM] cptcoleslaw#0000
I just also find loading/unloading ships to be the most annoying and tedious part of the game... so I like setting up consistent routes so that at each stop I know "load a, b, and c, unload x, y, and z, go" and it's pretty thoughtless and efficient


[01-Jun-24 06:48 PM] cptcoleslaw#0000
instead of "ok, I've got a ship at BEN now, where does it need to go? what does it need to take?"


[01-Jun-24 06:49 PM] cptcoleslaw#0000

[06-Jul-24 08:53 PM] riseoffilth#0000
Fun fact to everyone here. 

If you produce PE on a planet with 20 credits tax on Pios, that tax will charge you approx $5.4 credits per PE job, that produces 200 PE, worth $1800. That is 0.23% effective tax rate on your production valve.

If you make EDC, with a build time at 100% of one day, sale value of 11500, you get taxed less than 200 credits(assuming a tax rate of 600 for engineers), for an effective tax rate of 1.5%.

{Reactions}
ü§î 

[06-Jul-24 08:53 PM] riseoffilth#0000
always amazes me how little taxes actually take üòÑ

[30-Jul-24 06:23 PM] riseoffilth#0000
At the risk of speaking of grand economic theories, I think the CX is an incredibly poor metric and standard to hold any pricing to. An organized and coordinated internal market among a capable and diverse group of individuals, able to respond to supply changes and pricing manipulations, is the best possible way to ensure integrity and to prevent abuse. This is not to say we shouldnt participate in the market, but that we should keep lines of communication open and trading amongst ourselves flowing for important projects. In a perfect world, we would be able to produce enough supply to force the market to a certain price point and standardize things, but I fear that given this is a game lacking certain legal regulations, it would always be vulnerable to bad actors.


[30-Jul-24 06:23 PM] riseoffilth#0000
So, I will continue to work towards that and use a reasonable internal pricing.


[30-Jul-24 06:24 PM] riseoffilth#0000
So, on that, I can upgrade the INF to 8 for 900k, ezpz


[30-Jul-24 06:24 PM] riseoffilth#0000
next question


[30-Jul-24 06:28 PM] riseoffilth#0000
and you can too, for a higher price, but I think Nike can afford it. You could raise the taxes in line with other planets, (say a 10-20% depending on pop), but even if you didnt, youve run the planet for 2 years or something? When we start getting into the years territory, upgrading things to save on higher inputs and the ROI you get from it stops being as daunting.


[30-Jul-24 06:28 PM] riseoffilth#0000
Personally, I think its likely the game/server will still be running in a year or 2


[30-Jul-24 06:29 PM] riseoffilth#0000

[31-Jul-24 01:35 AM] finestone#0000
Setting up Pop Infrastructure and governing an outback planet sounds like a fun goal! it will be expensive and will need constant pop upkeep. though for really small pop planets with just pioneers i think just DW can last them a while. It also depends on which pops that you (and others) are going to use on the planet. Are other people going to go live out there with you? more people = more upkeep. So you will need a good financial base and some capitol to initiate.


[31-Jul-24 01:44 AM] finestone#0000
If you are simply wanting to setup the basic infrastructure for unsettled planets you wont have to go to far just try to find good planets. Then once people move in you could "hand off" the governship and upkeep to them and go "colonize" more planets but that will take time. The farther away the planet from a CX the less appealing due to transportation costs. You could also advertise giving people colonization "packs" that have a lot of the basic goods to entice them to move to your settled planets as an idea. All in all this will be a huge net drain on your wallet but could prove to be a fun time. Hope this summary helps.


[31-Jul-24 01:46 AM] realharvey#0000
You'll also have to run a lot of supplies down there in the beginning. And you need a lot of ships for that. The further away the more ships you are going to need


[31-Jul-24 02:38 AM] revoric#0000
Thanks! that all sounds like a fun goal to work toward


[31-Jul-24 02:38 AM] revoric#0000

[31-Jul-24 01:58 PM] jvaler#0000
i think that's a false dichotomy tbh

you just wanna optimize for consuming your entire agri output, which will always be best yield and best speed cause it's the most you can do with your agri.

low agri output is single input GRN C, higher output is a mix of single input and double input, higher than that is full double input, etc.


[31-Jul-24 01:59 PM] jvaler#0000
i guess the real question is "do i want more INC to run more single input orders or do i just want to use a higher input recipe"

[04-Aug-24 03:20 PM] akyantor#0000
I think the easiest way to consolodate an internal store is to ask folks to publish a CSV version of their store page in a prescribed format. You can then create a sheet that pulls each of them in (it'd require a one off action for each new storefront). *It's conceptually the same as how sidepipe, I and others, publish now, just switching from HTML to CSV, and in a consistant structure.*


[04-Aug-24 03:20 PM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
Idk what your're offering though. Short reccommend.


[04-Aug-24 03:21 PM] jvaler#0000
like what tanda has? https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/e/2PACX-1vTurW5x7j7Puz9hKpoI5wvLw0W0dr9OvkzDgMotlLT1NI8mE7cie_VWb1vmK5W6RZRo34mPQxCZRgaV/pubhtml?gid=1964780185&single=true

i've tried to extract data from these before but everything online says it isn't possible


[04-Aug-24 03:21 PM] akyantor#0000
There's an option to publish these as CSV rather than HTML.


[04-Aug-24 03:21 PM] akyantor#0000
Let me create an example


[04-Aug-24 03:24 PM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
Test it with someone in here....


[04-Aug-24 03:24 PM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
If it's easy, portable, ready to understand, and actionable, you may have something viable.


[04-Aug-24 03:26 PM] akyantor#0000
Here's an example for my storefront:
- [HTML Version](https://ingenious.foo/store)
- [CSV Version](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/e/2PACX-1vQyIiYe6LaI_KVXb6uIcf3XHnLOBdl3MxU5koX8JtnhCvhefnH_YDTzCVkbmT7qCF4QMxIvGVtMIVAP/pub?gid=2074260768&single=true&output=csv)

You can import the later into your own Google sheet using this formula: 
=IMPORTDATA("https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/e/2PACX-1vQyIiYe6LaI_KVXb6uIcf3XHnLOBdl3MxU5koX8JtnhCvhefnH_YDTzCVkbmT7qCF4QMxIvGVtMIVAP/pub?gid=2074260768&single=true&output=csv")


[04-Aug-24 03:27 PM] akyantor#0000
If everyone uses that same CSV format, then should be fairly straightforward to create a consolodated store.


[04-Aug-24 03:28 PM] jvaler#0000
oh and so if you only publish the sheet without the IMPORTDATA you can hide the auth key?


[04-Aug-24 03:28 PM] scintillating_iridescence#0000

[04-Aug-24 03:49 PM] jvaler#0000
the whole idea of this is to move the storefronts off of discord, that way stock can be updated by FIO instead of manually.

each person will have their own sheet template for them to input their data into (what's for sale, their prices, desired buffers, etc.), then they will publish their processed data into a web .csv.

i will then take everyone's published .csv's and compile them in my own spreadsheet so that everyone's information can be viewed and searched for in one place

[05-Aug-24 06:16 PM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
Profits are a thing. Uhm. ROIs of capital investment, versus expected returns, on a base are also a thing.


[05-Aug-24 06:17 PM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
Lower POPI tech production, like rats/dw offer good ROIs, but they're determined by your capital sinks in the bases. Higher tech production, basic example: EDC/IDC, offer better capital sinks, which turn over a greater # of money in game, but at a lesser sales turnover + marginal gain.


[05-Aug-24 06:17 PM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
Best that I can state it.

[05-Aug-24 06:27 PM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
Eh, you look fine. Private projects get accounted in very different ways from what the in-game accouting system is meant for. In-game accounting deals with pure CX-sales, minues CX-purchases, that were plugged into production ques. If you deal a lot with private project stuff, your in-game accounting won't look right.


[05-Aug-24 06:28 PM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
Lots of null cost item transfers, that get plugged into production costs as null values, that eventually get sold at the CX, at a huge profit? Idk.

[09-Aug-24 06:33 PM] scintillating_iridescence#0000

[09-Aug-24 06:38 PM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
It's also sort-of a Catch-22.... De-profit, a profitable industry (patented insulin manufacturing processes + sales/distribution), and you'll be cutting into the pension/retirement funds, that many, many public sector + well-to-do private sector employees are invested in. An alternative is needed, in that regard.


[09-Aug-24 06:44 PM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
Or not. But trying to fight/change some sort of social/financial relationship, that has been established for decades, including the amount of investment that many have hanging on potential outcomes, is a lost battle on paper.

[17-Aug-24 07:26 PM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
I do 1) **FLT + LMOS** on the first; 2) **CXOS + CONTS** on the second; 3) **FIN + FINLA + FINBS + FINIS + FXOS** on the third/fourth. [17-Aug-24 07:28 PM] scintillating_iridescence#0000

[20-Aug-24 04:08 AM] laaxus#0000
Question :
What is the maximal size of a base on a planet ?
I see that lvl 1 base has 500 area, and that an additionnal permit give 250 more.
So I guess the maximum size is 1000 area then you are forced to do another base on another planet ?


[20-Aug-24 04:11 AM] finestone#0000
yes and it is generally considered bad to use permits in that way as permits get very expensive so new planets are a more effective use of permit "space"


[20-Aug-24 04:12 AM] finestone#0000
there is a tradeoff for shipping and fuel cost and alot of people do still run "multi-permit" bases so do what you want!


[20-Aug-24 04:13 AM] laaxus#0000
It's hard to guess which side of the trade off is good


[20-Aug-24 04:13 AM] finestone#0000
It really depends on your size and how serious you want to play the game. If you are spending alot of time and are very wealthy (Pro membership, multiple ships) and want to maximize your optimazation you should not run multi permit bases. The only exception i can think of is maybe a super high end Corp HQ.

[20-Aug-24 09:31 AM] scintillating_iridescence#0000

{Attachments}

[20-Aug-24 11:55 AM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
You basically have a a period of quick growth, between B and R-fabs, that tends to get cripped by the exponential costs of A-fab HQ upgrade cost sinks.... That's where I think people are seriously reconsidering their tech utilization, when they are experiencing exponential costs, per month of HQ upgrades + base installations on inhospitable worlds, and they're trying to eek out as much money as they can.

{Attachments}
https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/1183249178156089374/1275498386711121981/Screenshot_from_2024-08-20_11-52-54.png?ex=6814f8f1&is=6813a771&hm=a077e5a5afa7a13bfbddd56c141bc77cda4c152f4f293c2ebdeafb5bb196654e&


[20-Aug-24 11:58 AM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
I'm not saying it's bad or anthing, it's just that EDC/IDC farmers have positioned themselves extremely well, 1-2 years beforehand, to benefit from the resultant supply increases of R/A-fabs + FIM/MEA, which are expected when the greater population seeks better margins, and thus competes with one another, through time.


[20-Aug-24 11:59 AM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
You also have the shipbuilders, but they're marginal in terms of net volumes of those things required, per month.


[20-Aug-24 12:00 PM] laaxus#0000

[20-Aug-24 12:02 PM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
Maybe, up to a certain point in the universal development.... We've passed it like 6 months ago. Now A-fabs are cheaper en masse, than R-fabs, which make IDCs more profitable than EDCs.... The same situation is happening with MEA, over FIM.


[20-Aug-24 12:02 PM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
Aggregate competition does wonders, to push down cost-metrics.


[20-Aug-24 12:11 PM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
Especially, when most people go chasing after those Prunplanner net_profit #s. It's just things to consider.

[20-Aug-24 12:16 PM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
You have a situation of margin squeeze. More suppliers/competitors, which will price another out per update of CXOS orders. More peeps in-game == this sort of thing happens much faster.

[21-Aug-24 08:29 AM] sidepipe#0000
~~do you mean for you, or for the devs?~~ (nvm it just clicked haha) because I'd _hate_ to know how many hours I've wasted fighting contracts üòÑ


[21-Aug-24 08:35 AM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
Those base CD-AAAA-XXXX numbers are randomly generated. Each person has a hidden ID, which connects those CD numbers, to their account, which are listed in descending order, from the date of creation. 

All you need, is a user generated, priority display #, which is easily had from a copy-pasta from anything on the Production Queue window... So yes... I'd hate to to know how many dev hours it would take, to do that.

https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/1183249178156089374/1275810500902387743/Screenshot_from_2024-08-21_08-32-17.png?ex=6814ca1e&is=6813789e&hm=7d7cca9073019840921ec33b7acfe619b4b58fb024c30d954b01982aa3ccf4b3&

What Is a Fixed Asset?
A fixed asset is a long-term tangible asset not expected to be used or sold within a year.
https://images-ext-1.discordapp.net/external/fi9Z6jQa3hYTsTd9yWemVDXmZL4b9BQ0fabErJNnl7Y/https/www.investopedia.com/thmb/RKtCfEEuXswsAgiArNjpmUK1Oz4%3D/1500x0/filters%3Ano_upscale%28%29%3Amax_bytes%28150000%29%3Astrip_icc%28%29/investing18-5bfc2b8fc9e77c005143f183.jpg

[22-Aug-24 10:57 AM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
Margin trading a commodity on a single CX. Margin trading between two CXes. Buying up cheap goodies at a LM, and shipping them over to a CX for sale.


[22-Aug-24 11:01 AM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
There's enough margin, between any of those three, for such things to be viable... You just need to know your commodity markets. Of course, viability simply includes some marginal profit rate, which is far less than ideal, on say a single order transaction. It's best done long-term. Just ask Mr. Insulcris regarding how viable such things are.

[23-Aug-24 06:46 AM] laaxus#0000
with 2 recuring order, does it alternate ?

{Attachments}
https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/1183249178156089374/1276507960855760997/image.png?ex=6814b0ae&is=68135f2e&hm=436bd73eec303ee9cc0139a2891ab5f89e79f828d43d0415c63e87996ff313d4&


[23-Aug-24 06:52 AM] tanda#0000
yes, as long as a recipe can be run (you have the ingredients) it will alternate as slots open up


[23-Aug-24 06:53 AM] tanda#0000
and that scales up, too. If you have 7 recurring orders, the top 1 will go to the bottom of the order queue when it gets started

neat

[23-Aug-24 09:27 AM] laaxus#0000
is there any way to show the burn for the inventory of a base, like for the consumables ?


[23-Aug-24 09:28 AM] riseoffilth#0000
download the PMMG extension on firefox or another browser that it works on


[23-Aug-24 09:28 AM] riseoffilth#0000
follow the installation process, make an account, etc


[23-Aug-24 09:28 AM] riseoffilth#0000
then the command "XIT burn_[planetid]"


[23-Aug-24 09:29 AM] laaxus#0000
incredible, thanks


[23-Aug-24 09:29 AM] riseoffilth#0000
be aware, if you change recipes, the data of "burn" still lists the old items, and if you lack those items, it will falsely tell you that you are out


[23-Aug-24 09:29 AM] riseoffilth#0000
you would have to wipe your cache to correct

[25-Aug-24 03:43 AM] akyantor#0000
There will always be demand for BDE as folks need it to expand / repair existing bases, whereas there **may **be a smaller pool of available buyers for the intermediary product.


[25-Aug-24 03:44 AM] laaxus#0000
i see


[25-Aug-24 03:47 AM] akyantor#0000
That said.. a lot of people have the same opinion about the buy/sell point for intermediary products. I tend to lean towards buying consumables, but building out the full supply chain for an end product (for example I make nearly all the products to enable me to make bfab/lfab - which makes expansion very cheap for me as I'm only paying the consumable cost). There are plenty of folks who don't do that though.


[25-Aug-24 03:49 AM] akyantor#0000
I was offering the bfabs/lfabs to ADI, but in a rapid expansion phase at the moment so is currently unavailable. It's thoroughly relevant, in that --- all the newbros who ask questions, within in-game COMGs, are getting sent directly to the APEX wiki links... And they are told to learn all of it, exactly. Since ANT starter planets are not being mentioned within the starter profession recommendations --- you're basically losing potential market share, of what will eventually be, in 1-2 years.


[31-Aug-24 08:21 PM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
.... Initial conditions largely dictate individual company expansions, opportunity cost, options... Et.c. E.g. A starter in Insitor space, with x2 500 t/m3 FTL ships, would not want to expand to ANT space, before a certain HQ and ship # basis... IF they would instead have started out in ANT (Harmonia/Deimos, or others), they would be immediately incentive'd with expanding their operations in ANT space, and not HRT, BEN, or anything else, due to #reasons. <---- is done.

[03-Sep-24 10:02 AM] laaxus#0000
So yeah, to find the best investment, you have to consider many option. Ofcourse the recipe profit is a great indicator, but it does  no matter if you can't sell your production long term, or if you can't supply. Therefore, the number of available bidders, the volume and weight of the recipe and the distance from the cx all matters. However, with a clever mix of recipes, you can reduce the shipping cost and therefore increase overall profit in some case. But there's more to it, for example, the ...

BRM only base makes 521/d on 840c....
16 CHP on REA needs 917.14... if you add 1 EXT to the CHP with 1 expert that cuts it down to 884.63... import 364 BRM/d or get a second base to support you
12 CHP / 4 EXT would need 567/d, yield 274 REA/d import 46 BRM/d
or 4/2 expert would be 517/d, yield 255 REA/d

[21-Sep-24 03:45 AM] cruelcoin#0000
Morning all.


[21-Sep-24 03:45 AM] cruelcoin#0000
Can i ask where the margins come from in this game?


[21-Sep-24 03:46 AM] cruelcoin#0000
As in, (excluding giga companies like amazon etc), in a healthy market with healthy competition, markets tend towards 7-10% profit.
Companies compete away eachothers margins to that point (ideally).


[21-Sep-24 03:47 AM] cruelcoin#0000
But the margins on my Ration production for example are way in excess of that.


[21-Sep-24 03:53 AM] evov#0000
Correct me if I'm wrong, but I think you're talking about valuation, not profit, when you're referring to the 7-10% profit for companies?

I think mostly, in both rl and in prun, the question comes down to.... How much return can I get on my money +consider risk +consider cognitive load/time availability.

{Reactions}
üëÜ 

[21-Sep-24 03:55 AM] cruelcoin#0000
I think it is net profit for that %.
It's only logical too that companies will spring up to seize margin, to the point of loss of attractiveness.


[21-Sep-24 03:56 AM] cruelcoin#0000
Could it be the sign of an aging/maturing player base that's moving towards higher end production?


[21-Sep-24 03:56 AM] cruelcoin#0000
Thus reducing production on the entry level?


[21-Sep-24 03:59 AM] evov#0000
Well, there are limitations in the game. We can't have 100 bases. Bases are limited in size. There are limited developed planets where you can build bases. So we're forced to choose between this thing, or that thing.


[21-Sep-24 04:02 AM] evov#0000
I would say.... there's 2 primary measures of profitability in the game.... 2 ways people measure how juicy a base/building/production line etc is.

1. RoI - How quickly does a thing pay for itself.
2. $/Area - How much $ per day can you squeeze out of a permit.


[21-Sep-24 04:04 AM] evov#0000
When newish - (less than 20 permits say) - RoI tends to be the most important thing. You just want to be growing and expanding and building more bases more faster.

After 20ish permits - the permit cost starts being more expensive than the cost of building the base. At this point, it's generally a bit more important to maximize the $ you can squeeze out of each permit each day, rather than trying to multiply money faster.

{Reactions}
üëç (2) 

[21-Sep-24 04:10 AM] cruelcoin#0000
Makes sense, thank you.


[21-Sep-24 04:10 AM] skyrey#0000
The answer is a lot simpler:

1 - under population of the world. There are numerous potential industries and niches in the market - but only a few thousand players in total. 

2 - High paced production and the ability to change the entire production line in a day at a minuscule comparable cost allows active players to be very efficient. With this advantage over reality players can be significantly more efficient

{Reactions}
üëç 

[21-Sep-24 04:11 AM] skyrey#0000
Thus high profit margins


[21-Sep-24 04:11 AM] cruelcoin#0000
I'm trying to set up PRUN in such a way that it doesn't mark water as a profit item where i produce it, nor as a cost in the base i ship it to to be consumed.


[21-Sep-24 04:11 AM] skyrey#0000
It is a profit item as if you later on use it yourself. That profit from one base is taken on as a cost of production in the other


[21-Sep-24 04:12 AM] cruelcoin#0000
But to keep it level in terms of same value in/out, i should set my cx preferences for water to be average for my local market?


[21-Sep-24 04:13 AM] skyrey#0000
I for example grow Grain and use it to make Carbon. But my water and grain production outpaces my Carbon intake. Thus I sell the excess as additional profit


[21-Sep-24 04:15 AM] skyrey#0000
Well. If water was a sell of 100 and a bid of 90. By supplying the water directly to yourself rather than selling it to the CX at 90. You do not have to pay the 100 per unit of water for your second base. Thus this vertical production system saves you 10 spread per unit of water used


[21-Sep-24 04:17 AM] skyrey#0000
If you set it up average, it will not account for you supplying yourself at more favourable prices. Bypassing players who engage in commodity arbitrage


[21-Sep-24 04:17 AM] cruelcoin#0000
I see.
So 110c set water sell price to cx bid, and 110b set water buy price to cx bid.


[21-Sep-24 04:17 AM] cruelcoin#0000
Makes sense, thank you.


[21-Sep-24 04:21 AM] skyrey#0000
If we look at Anteras CX:

If you sell water, you get 36 per unit.

If you buy water, you pay 44.80 per unit.

If you were to sell your water from one base and buy the water for another, then what you are asking about makes sense.

But because you produce the water yourself, you are able to sell it to yourself at 36 per unit. Saving you 8.80 per unit


[21-Sep-24 04:38 AM] cruelcoin#0000
Ok. Bear with me please.
My thinking then is:
- Empire buy price is the local cx buy price (assuming i'm buying everything i don't produce myself).
- Empire sell price is the local cx sell price (assumes i sell everything i'm not shipping to another planet)
- To cover where water is being sent to another base of mine, i set that planets water sell price to cx sell.
- that receiving planets water buy price is set to cx sell for the cheaper rate?

As in screenshot? Have i understood you correctly?

{Attachments}
https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/1183249178156089374/1286984880684531752/ScreenHunter_11.jpg?ex=68149292&is=68134112&hm=a94cdfadbd74e7900d8e48a3ab8e29efc54d674e7dee63bbc89026908a5bce19&


[21-Sep-24 04:39 AM] jvaler#0000
bids(green) in this game get traded on much less than asks(red), so their prices are commonly out of date to real market trends. ask/ask is much more reliable, or better yet use the 7d average setting for both

{Reactions}

[21-Sep-24 11:18 AM] kynadre#0000

[21-Sep-24 11:18 AM] jcheung#0000
got some examples?


[21-Sep-24 11:20 AM] jcheung#0000
ship speeds are constrained by a couple different things, i don't know all of them, but here are a few...
ship mass, engine thrust, squishy tolerance (g-factor)
the starter ship, engine thrust is high enough that even at max ship mass, you wouldn't survive at max thrust... so it throttles down

{Reactions}
üëç 

[21-Sep-24 11:20 AM] jcheung#0000
if you install a high-g seat, then the limitation switches over to ship mass because you can burn harder

{Reactions}
üëç 

[21-Sep-24 11:25 AM] kynadre#0000

[21-Sep-24 12:14 PM] jcheung#0000
It can be, i do something similar sometimes.
It mostly depends on what cargo needs to be moved. In your example, it would be very easy to say.... for example, pack consumables for both deimos and nike, then pack feedstock (ore, flx, o, etc) for deimos.
Once there, pick up whatever AL/FE or other materials you made and head to nike with nike consumables and the refined metals.

You likely will still need to make some dedicated runs for that, but it makes more sense than backtracking the refined metal to ANT since deimos is between ANT and nike

[21-Sep-24 01:27 PM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
I mean, MAYBE, STL travel in ANT, would be more viable than in BEN, based on the orbits themselves... But people don't play this game for that; they need stuff transported, whenever they deem it so --- thus its best to bet on the best metrics (FSE stl engines), and simply hope for the best.


[21-Sep-24 04:26 PM] evov#0000
I recognise that shipping can be a constraint for people. But generally, I refuse to accept shipping contracts because there's no way to know if they're auto supplied or not. As in... they may not have the stuff ready to go when my ship is actually there with empty space. Buying the stuff on planet and picking it up myself is just easier.

{Reactions}
üëç (2)

[21-Sep-24 05:07 PM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
From what I've seen, shipping contracts have defaulted to FSE fuel use rates + depreciation value... They're not paying for the premium of service, rather they're defaulting to the least common denominator of some sort of contractually assured servicing... I'm not buying into that at all. Evov has his fair points as well. 

You've basically got a propaganda machine going on.. "Ohh hey.. it's extra income, I might as well just take it"... Well half of the galaxy is assuming people will do such that, and they're basing their rates off of such... 

This has been going on for years, so it's less of a gripe, and more of an observation.

{Reactions}
üëç

[22-Sep-24 06:40 AM] laaxus#0000

[22-Sep-24 06:46 AM] evov#0000
That's a very small % of the trade between the 2 cx's. I think the only thing the FX market is representative of, is the net sum of people who like using the FX market.


[22-Sep-24 06:55 AM] evov#0000
Since I've been tracking my CX activity - From this friday going back 41 days...
My CX Sales at Benten - 21mil
My CX Buys at Benten - 29mil

People will often use MM products (IDC/EDC/CBL etc) to transfer cash between CX's. That far exceeds whatever volume the fx market does imo


[22-Sep-24 07:01 AM] evov#0000
ANT and MOR are typically more expensive for most of the consumables and things like that. Compared to HRT and BEN, ANT and MOR are generally just more highly developed. We make more high end stuff here.

But the price difference in consumes / fuel etc isn't massive.  e.g. -> Consumes price index for each of the areas.

[23-Sep-24 11:42 AM] pxlfox.#0000
can someone explain to me what's a ticker and what's a buffer in apex?


[23-Sep-24 11:42 AM] pxlfox.#0000
My guess is - if I open a new window and enter a command, what I get shown is a ticker.


[23-Sep-24 11:43 AM] pxlfox.#0000
fixing it to a specific screen is a buffer?


[23-Sep-24 11:43 AM] razenpok#0000
buffer is any floating window in apex


[23-Sep-24 11:43 AM] razenpok#0000
But people also call any docked tile as buffer also


[23-Sep-24 11:43 AM] razenpok#0000
Ticker is a material abbreviation, for example ticker of Iron is FE


[23-Sep-24 11:44 AM] razenpok#0000
A ticker can have a CX id in it, for example AL.AI1


[23-Sep-24 11:45 AM] jvaler#0000
which is WRONG and EVIL do not fall victim to this

[23-Sep-24 09:32 PM] evov#0000
All of the price models have their own issues. There is no "correct" choice. But you should understand the pros/cons of whatever option you're using.
Time averaged data (e.g. PP7D_AI1 ) falls down a bit when there's sharp movements in the AI market. It means you'll be late to the party to realize you're losing money or making the wrong thing etc.

[24-Sep-24 06:18 AM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
While CU might be attractive... You're still looking at a surplus market for it on the CX. It's an intermediate product, with no immediate-end use customer on the other side of any sales transaction. You're better off redoubling on vertical integration with that metal, at least on the metallurgical side, since it'll cut down on overall logistical requirements...

And the end-use | retail markets for any of those CU derivative products are niche, and have little sales turnover on a daily/weekly cycle.

Here's your path to getting the copper ore base you want - 
Figuire out what it'll cost you.  ( you'll want 3 x WCB ships to handle the volume/distance) I can deliver that to you by the end of the week if you've got the $$ for it. Your base, will cost you 1.5mil + some amount of consumables. I'd suggest at least a couple weeks.. might take time for your CUO to sell.

So maybe allow 2mil for the base+consumes. And the ships are 5.6mil each.

So you'll want an 18.8mil loan. Have a chat to some of the loan providers and find out what that looks like.

[24-Sep-24 10:27 AM] manhim#0000
Being diverse requires you to stay on top of more markets and exposes you to more risks, but is generally going to be more profitable.


[24-Sep-24 10:27 AM] pxlfox.#0000
But doesn't it make you less volatile to market change?


[24-Sep-24 10:27 AM] manhim#0000
Going vertical means that you own more aspects of your own supply chain, so there is less risks.


[24-Sep-24 10:27 AM] pxlfox.#0000
like if AL prices drop, basically all my profit atm does too


[24-Sep-24 10:28 AM] manhim#0000
It's the amount of risks exposed, but each risks are more isolated from each bases basically.


[24-Sep-24 10:29 AM] razenpok#0000
Producing diverse goods is safer than producing one good
Producing things vertically is safer than producing things using CX for inputs


[24-Sep-24 10:29 AM] razenpok#0000
That's two axes of risk-management


[24-Sep-24 10:30 AM] razenpok#0000
Safe, but less profit ofc


[24-Sep-24 10:32 AM] manhim#0000
Vertical integration also allows you to stockpile materials and use them when the price of those material rise, so you're more resilient to market changes.

But if your end-product crashes, your whole vertical integration could collapse as well.


[24-Sep-24 10:32 AM] pxlfox.#0000

[24-Sep-24 11:38 AM] cptcoleslaw#0000
Yeah, BMPs can be more active management to keep profitable, but just because of the diversity of recipe options they're pretty consistently profitable if you pay attention. Get PRUNplanner CX settings set up good and keep an eye on what the most profitable recipe is. Do a mix of the highest profit recipes, paying attention to actual traded volume. If input prices go up or output price goes down and your margin gets smaller, just switch to a different recipe. ¬Ø\_(„ÉÑ)_/¬Ø

[25-Sep-24 03:58 AM] pxlfox.#0000
Is there any reason not to start productions with settlers, other then the higher supply costs?


[25-Sep-24 04:25 AM] evov#0000
Depends on the planet. Sometimes higher teir pops aren't present in high numbers on a planet, so you have to wait for pop to fill. This is unlikely to be the case for setlers, but something to keep in mind when going up the worker tiers.


[25-Sep-24 04:26 AM] evov#0000
Usually... Settler tier buildings are more expensive, so build cost and repair costs typically go up along with worker tier (roughly)

üíØ 

[25-Sep-24 05:13 AM] kynadre#0000
*can't sleep for other reasons but bouncing up and down waiting for the market haul home to max out the base*


[25-Sep-24 05:26 AM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
I'd just like to point out, that the Prunner | Prunplanner software(s) were intended to simply base design | planning for people, as they basically do the same matrix multiplication that any spreadsheet does [i.e. lots of concurrent calculations that transpose production ratios, and material stats, into something human readable]. 

Market activity/reality, however is driven by player choice and preference. While you might have strong correlations, regarding PP metrics, at any given point, those metrics are just underlined with assumptions, and may not represent any tangible reality, into the long-term.


[25-Sep-24 05:31 AM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
But the general maths of how Prun works, is that you pick something to do, and then do it in the long term. Your invariable colony costs (HABs, STOs) eventually fully depreciate over 6 months. You'll usually get max experts, on whatever you do on a base, within 45 to 180 days. You'll soon be able to pitch in BID orders for all of your weekly production inputs + consumables + repair mats, and should sales turnover be whimsical on the ASK orders at any CX, you can always ask around to see who would be willing to purchase whatever you make, at any given price point (provided you have done your homework, and maintain at least a BASIC license).

{Reactions}
üëç 

[25-Sep-24 05:33 AM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
Do all of that, and you'll probably be fairly insulated from whatever the market throws at you. Of course, should you deem it necessary to just deconstruct that permit due to "market forces", you'll just be losing all of that long-term infrastructure, and experts, and you might regret such a decision, when the next month rolls around.

{Reactions}
this 

[25-Sep-24 05:43 AM] kynadre#0000
learning to read trends, esp. over the last 30, 60, 90 days, daily trades volume, volumes already (over)stuffed on market, seeing the production chains to see how much it's actually used,


[25-Sep-24 05:45 AM] kynadre#0000
and of course, how much it's going to require your ships to be moving every day...


[25-Sep-24 05:55 AM] evov#0000
Again, I'm not intending to shit on PP as a tool, because it can be great. The issue is the false confidence it inspires in people. So a few points people need to... more strongly consider.

1. Shipping costs. When you look at the roi number or the profits etc, none of it mentions shipping. It does an AWESOME job of working out the daily volume/mass requirement, even if I don't really agree with the way it's calculated. But people rarely consider how that translates into the ongoing cost of shipping, or the captial expense (what % of a ship will this base soak up)

2. Pricing - There's a lot of different pricing methods. They all have pro's and cons (the pros and cons of the different methods could be an entire discussion on its own). Understand that there are different options, they will yield different results, and for the love of god stop looking at a base planner using one specific set of pricing models and think it somehow represents with certainty the ground truth of the matter.


[25-Sep-24 06:00 AM] evov#0000
The things it does really well ( I use it for this most of the time )

Base planning - Playing around with building counts, mixing between HB1/2 etc and the split HABs HBC etc. It's awesome for that. I did build that functionality into a spreadsheet before PP was a thing.... I discontinued that part of my sheets once PP came out.

Once you've got a base built/planned/modeled - It does a really good job of material flows. Seeing how much AL / H2O etc you're consuming and using across multiple buildings using different recipies. I think this element is great and can be helpful for scaling bases when setting up multi base projects.  ( For very large / complicated projects, I'd still use custom sheets however. But for 2 or 3 base setups, pp works great )

The planet search is a really nice tool. New to me, but I'd give it a thumbs up. Still - people need to consider the jumps/distance and how that will affect shipping requirements when using this tool.

{Reactions}
üíØ 

[25-Sep-24 06:01 AM] evov#0000
Oh, also the list of materials needed when building a new planned base, that works great also.

{Reactions}
üíØ 

[25-Sep-24 06:01 AM] laaxus#0000
The best feature of prunplanner is the CX settings imo


[25-Sep-24 06:02 AM] evov#0000
Disagree.


[25-Sep-24 06:03 AM] kynadre#0000
re: values I think the best way to use those is 
1) is this already flagged as a loss production if you were to buy at insta-buy and sell at insta-sell? 
2) if not, what are your investment costs that eat into your revenues? 
If your revenues are REALLY high compared to "profit", consider this item a PITA item
3) if that isn't bad, look at the estimated hauling m3/t per day
4) if that isn't bad, actually look at the market to see supply/demand, trends over 60 days, current listings & how many of those are super-stuffed you can ignore, etc.

Basically, it helps you see what you want to research further in game. But most importantly it helps you see red flags if you know where to look


[25-Sep-24 06:08 AM] evov#0000
One of the things you'll eventually run into as you move into higher tier production.... often the CX data isn't great. The volume of trades is low and out-dated. Over-reliance on whatever PP shows, means people are less inclined to actually check the data they're using... where's it comming from, is it dependable/up to date.  For making rats and low tier, market saturated items... it's probably fine (mostly). It's just really important to know where you're getting the numbers from, and why.

{Reactions}

[25-Sep-24 06:37 AM] laaxus#0000

[25-Sep-24 06:38 AM] laaxus#0000

[25-Sep-24 06:38 AM] evov#0000

[25-Sep-24 06:39 AM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
Mmm. I'd prefer to leave the overall decision of "how much should I charge for this", up to a given player, since most could have a variety of operational decisions to take, regarding what they make. 

But looking at Prunplanners screen overview... Once you've setup your Input price flows... You then just take your daily Costs + Depreciation, and divide them, with your daily unit outputs. (you can do a weighted cut, if your base is a mixed-output setup). That'll get you with approximate break evens, for you to make your decision on.


[25-Sep-24 06:39 AM] laaxus#0000
I Can tell you that in 30-45 min once I'm home


[25-Sep-24 07:54 AM] archielvahr#0000
I think it's not that I don't know what CX setting prunplanner is pulling, it's that I don't know if it's reasonable. Like I just made a planet to smelt LIO into LI. You can set it to ANT CX BID or ANT CX ASK or PP30_Universe (my preference). But as EvoV said  you have to understand that _none_ of those numbers might really make sense. And a lot of times they can fluctuate wildly. 

Some people pick one and decide it's an authoritative and actual representation of their product's value, when it's really just a very wiggly number. Turns out LI at 1800 vs 1600 ends up being very different for my base's profitability. And it traded at both those numbers in the last 24 hours:

{Attachments}
https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/1183249178156089374/1288483673607241778/image.png?ex=6814c06e&is=68136eee&hm=ff6b8573ab5370d9b4eabf71b6f779b2605a4961fdbe24afefcb659bec9913ed&


[25-Sep-24 07:56 AM] archielvahr#0000
So when you set it your CX settings, sure you can remember what they are, but you don't know the current price it's using. And you can't actually see that number on this page:

{Attachments}
https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/1183249178156089374/1288484154979258469/image.png?ex=6814c0e1&is=68136f61&hm=d49ac849e11ce5a5c27fa19c90fdd156b3a1e36cc2a502b892f6e5f8f6ff1131&


[25-Sep-24 07:56 AM] archielvahr#0000
So you can drill down and click on Cost of Goods Manufactured... And it also doesn't show it here:

[25-Sep-24 12:40 PM] kynadre#0000
Since I'm trying to understand and learn more (of course...), I have a question about the screen setups. In some cases multiple sections resize together, and in others they don't... with screenshots with lines it'll make more sense...

{Attachments}
https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/1183249178156089374/1288555759516254208/image.png?ex=68150391&is=6813b211&hm=35fedb02f99ec6d15df581fd9deedf3abd65b4cc15320c00328f228525d26a30&


[25-Sep-24 12:41 PM] igfloz#0000
You can drag (resize) each buffer horizontally and vertically to make them match up. I normally start by creating a new screen and then quartering it


[25-Sep-24 12:42 PM] kynadre#0000
So, with the red lines, if I raise one of the two sections up or down, both raise up or down together. The yellow lines aren't affected by how the red lines move. Similarly, the yellow lines move up or down together, and don't affect the red

{Attachments}
https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/1183249178156089374/1288556152765812808/image.png?ex=681503ef&is=6813b26f&hm=a57bd69358bde372898f8710a96ac3f45ca40f23918bb9ba5a3122b2fcb6d4d7&


[25-Sep-24 12:42 PM] kynadre#0000
How do I subdivide so that the red lines and/or the yellow lines can be further subdivided, so I have more separate height control for each subgroup?


[25-Sep-24 12:43 PM] igfloz#0000
They both raise, because you sliced a buffer vertically (but they are still kinda attached)

{Reactions}
üëç 

[25-Sep-24 12:43 PM] kynadre#0000

[25-Sep-24 12:43 PM] jcheung#0000
Pop the two bottom out to floating buffers


[25-Sep-24 12:43 PM] jcheung#0000
Then delete the tiles


[25-Sep-24 12:43 PM] jcheung#0000
Then split the columns


[25-Sep-24 12:43 PM] igfloz#0000
I don't know. I tend to build my layout 1st, then copy paste screen codes into each


[25-Sep-24 12:44 PM] kynadre#0000

[25-Sep-24 12:44 PM] igfloz#0000

[25-Sep-24 12:45 PM] jcheung#0000
Once columns are split, then the two columns will move left/right together but up/down for the two sub tiles will be independent for each column

üëç 

[27-Sep-24 12:05 PM] jcheung#0000
when a recurring order is pushed into a production slot, it immediately goes to the bottom of the queue stack


[27-Sep-24 12:05 PM] jcheung#0000
like so

üëç 

[27-Sep-24 12:14 PM] kynadre#0000

[27-Sep-24 12:15 PM] jcheung#0000
leaves you a slot for manual injection and reduces the stockpile size you need on AL

{Reactions}
üëç 

[27-Sep-24 12:15 PM] jcheung#0000
also just to make sure, this is what i mean, this slider controls how many batches are run off per queue slot

{Attachments}
https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/1183249178156089374/1289274262649180201/image.png?ex=6814fdb9&is=6813ac39&hm=6bcaf378a0b1346af14645e395b65455a67437d0607caf6213ca622b0039b70c&

{Reactions}
üëç 

[27-Sep-24 12:16 PM] jcheung#0000
so in prunplanner your goal is to just tweak batch sizes to get your output/d to be in line with whatever you're trying to do-produce x, or consume x amount

{Reactions}
üëç 

[27-Sep-24 12:18 PM] jcheung#0000
then you export the ratio of batches into your production queue


[27-Sep-24 12:18 PM] jcheung#0000
oh. one last thing


[27-Sep-24 12:19 PM] jcheung#0000
if a recurring order is unable to be performed due to lack of materials


[27-Sep-24 12:19 PM] jcheung#0000
it will tie up one production slot and the second queued item will jump the queue when a second production slot opens up

{Reactions}
üëç 

[27-Sep-24 12:20 PM] jcheung#0000
if you have 3 things that can't be done, then it'll tie up 3 production slots and the 4th will go


[27-Sep-24 12:20 PM] jcheung#0000
...actually i think it might just apply in general to all orders, recurring or not

{Reactions}
üëç

[27-Sep-24 01:42 PM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
```
Mothers and daughters (do wit), give me a call as I'm (or you're) usually free,
But be warned, that you shouldn't dither with a plea;
All I want in life, is to be truly free,
But that's because I'm usually in life's spree.
```

Read into it, what you want? My ear tingled with a rhyme, befitting the theme. üòõ

[27-Sep-24 02:21 PM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
Of course, a couple sets of eyes looking over anything, does wonder.... You'd have like a better "Lore section" on the APEX wiki, if the devs would flick on the green light for community contributions. It's hard to come by though, with only like a handful of entries. 

I do keep the custom requests I've done for others, though...

Regarding, say, VH-331c (Beanironia):

```
The stout and steadfast farmers of VH-331a, faced a dilemma in the near past, being troubled by the means of their toiling about, were brought to realize the nature of their caste. They drivelled amongst another: 'We labor all day and night, and we yield nothing short of a mountain of bean. Yet we grow dismal in our plight, as we have nothing else to improve our scene!'. 

And so a few lofty souls set out to VH-331c, deeming their goal as noble and worthy, to burn by fire, the exact thing with which they all desire. To convert by combustion, and to claim those trace metals of much need, bothering not to lend credit on any sensible heed. And so they dithered, and withered, for years on end, gaining very little to contribute towards what they wanted to extend. Through the effort, a few gave demur: 'We have none of this, yet all of that -- to where else shall we be cast?'. Yet under their feet by which they stood, lay an irony that is truly vast.

-----------------------------------

There's a few morals actually shoved in there. Opportunity costs, of doing your thing efficiently, versus doing something inefficiently. Seeking input from others. Resource density concerns. Commodity t/m3 concerns, especially when shipping things over....
```

{Reactions}
‚ô•Ô∏è 

[27-Sep-24 02:22 PM] kynadre#0000
#1 thing, and I don't mean it as an offense as I'm guilty, too, as are like 50%+ of English writers: when to comma, and when not to


[27-Sep-24 02:23 PM] kynadre#0000
there is a veritable fountain of commas springing forth that doth make me suspect your comma key is half-sprung and on edge of breakage XDD ‚ù§Ô∏è


[27-Sep-24 02:23 PM] kynadre#0000
also, it'll significantly help with flow, which is the reason I bring it up :this:


[27-Sep-24 02:26 PM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
When you enforce the "modern" standards, yes my comma usage is rather asinine, but I use the commas to enforce dependent clauses. It's hard to notice in text, since most are usually de-sensitised to the mountain of drivel that they read through each day. If I were to drop voice recordings here, it would be much more noticeable, regarding my intonation, and participle clauses for any set of ideas.


[27-Sep-24 02:28 PM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
I type as I would like to speak. It's rather drawn out in-text, and as such it is a poor-read.


[27-Sep-24 02:28 PM] kynadre#0000
it also indicates that you're breaking mid-clause, and as a transcriber I can confirm that vocal styles are indeed punctuated differently by commas and periods than they are punctuated by breath verbally


[27-Sep-24 02:28 PM] kynadre#0000
they are in fact two completely different sets of norms

{Reactions}
üëÜ 

[27-Sep-24 02:28 PM] kynadre#0000
I was literally trained (and certified) in it ^^


[27-Sep-24 02:33 PM] kynadre#0000

[27-Sep-24 02:34 PM] kynadre#0000

[27-Sep-24 02:36 PM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
I wonder if any said vocalities, actually do go to the gym? A developed capacity for pleural capacity, could perhaps modify such tendencies? This of course is a #hard question, since you probably know very well the set of personages who do partake in the activities that you're interested in. 

But I'll state that almost the entirely of the Middle | Early - Modern English, is entirely dependent on abitrary declinations made evident in certain publications, which were then thoroughly published and advertised as a de-facto standard for a "modern" British Empire. Before that, much of the written, and spoken discourse, was entirely free-form, with emphasis on the sounded form of the words and sentences, rather than with any conventional style. 

I'm just old fashioned, and how I write just seems natural to me? :/

[27-Sep-24 03:26 PM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
Prun devs are actually doing a good job for the most part. They have limited funding, and they want to keep in-game content rolling into the future, and with the gateway possibilities, you're looking at tangible cost cutting, regarding player realities. Of course, there's significant "investment considerations" at play, but if those things are just rendered to "on-principle" returns, you'll then be looking at significant operational realities, in like 1-2 years. 

Most of the current FTL shipbuilding has been had within the same period. When me, Evov, or others were first diddling with Prun... There was nothing of the sort available for purchase @ UFO, or elsewhere, aside from GTUs pilot programs. Prun is a **very** long-term game.

[27-Sep-24 03:37 PM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
Permit investment is a thing as well. But if you're going to be logging in, for years... That stuff is just an operational inconvenience. It's a good metric to tender to those youths in Prun... But after several years of profitable gains compounding themselves.... It just turns into a daily churn.


[27-Sep-24 03:49 PM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
#Hazy_Fuzz? Maybe. You've got several "margin" enthusiasts who are keen on the EDC/IDC revenues. There's others who are potentially more quiet regarding their operational goals, regarding those things. 

But what you usually get, is an immediately "liquefied" commodity, which you can easily transport to a CX | Currency of interest, within 1-2 days, which will likely net you such liquidity, at better rates, than what the FX market can absorb on a weekly basis. I've done the analysis for a friend, maybe 2 months ago. 

Maybe one of you can retort against me, with better info as to why peeps are doing the EDC/IDC.... But I'm usually of the opinion that you can sink serious capital into those operations easily, and it'll net you healthy operational revenues (from capital investment #s via PP, or some other solution * daily profit proceeds). 

But you'll get better ROIs/turnovers with most PIO | SET processes...

You'll get better margins with whatever remains of the PIO |SET processes...

You'll get much better margins, but lower turnovers on the higher stuff...

And everything else in-between, will depend on how fast you can move your production, on the CX, and also through private contracts.


[27-Sep-24 03:50 PM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
Evov plopped like 5 days ago why they needed to get into EDC | IDC stuff. They needed the operational revenue.. It's the traditional argument for such things.


[27-Sep-24 03:52 PM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
We're like what? 700+ days in-game... The arguments for EDC | IDC, were originally conceived within the confines of private interest groups, some -650 days after that. It's "been a long road"?

[03-Oct-24 05:13 AM] shrewdsun_88540#0000
Just one more loan‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs good for you


[03-Oct-24 05:28 AM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
Yes, just open up the Workforce buffer, on any of your bases. Non used POP tiers will be greyed out, but you still get the base metrics there. For those that you do use, you just divide out what they're using per day, in a ratio of 100 (so if you employ 1800 PIOs, just divide out daily usage by 18).

{Reactions}

[05-Oct-24 05:55 AM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
Yeah. Peer-to-peer material transfer conts follow the same rubric as CX purchase overflow conts, with just the simple addition, or removal, of a payment term. You don't see such things often, though.

But shipping conts are a whole different monster, as exact space is required, since the stuff is transferred into an escrow of 1 unit each.

I think the numbers pulled from FIO for natural resources allow you to calculate the amount produced per day, then you actually have to work backwards to get the recipe time. So the amount per day will probably come out right even when the quantity and recipe time are off

[12-Oct-24 03:19 AM] laaxus#0000

[12-Oct-24 03:20 AM] evov#0000
No idea, I have a bajillion ships so I don't out-source shipping. I just know that when I fill up a load to go from ANT to MOR - I'd expect it to make 50-100k on average. So 30 just seems a little low.


[12-Oct-24 03:21 AM] laaxus#0000
I'll see


[12-Oct-24 03:21 AM] laaxus#0000

[12-Oct-24 03:25 AM] evov#0000
Just to put it in perspective - 30k, minus roughly 5k in fuel for the trip if you go slow and stretch it out to nearly 2 days = 25k.

That's about what the daily interest accrual is on the sort of loan you'd likely need to buy one of those ships.

Which is why about 50k is usually the min I'd be looking to make on a trip like that when doing any CX-CX trading.


[12-Oct-24 03:26 AM] laaxus#0000
if someone had to move a ship from Ant to moria for another purpose, he'd be happy to earn 25k on that trip, rather than -5k


[12-Oct-24 03:26 AM] laaxus#0000
your argument is sound from an investment pov


[12-Oct-24 03:27 AM] laaxus#0000
but it's different from market price


[12-Oct-24 03:29 AM] evov#0000
Or maybe they've got plenty of ships sitting around doing nothing, but don't have enough money to buy their own PE in ANT and sell it in MOR. There's plenty of potential scenario's - I'm just pointing out the economics of it is all.

[12-Oct-24 12:33 PM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
You want at least 30k in returns, from say a LCB contract. Better yet if you can pull off 60k, from shipping inefficiencies, which make themselves known in the LMs (eventually)... At 60k returns, you're basically at 1/2 the ROI rates that you'd otherwise get from pushing the capital investment into new HQ permits.

[17-Oct-24 09:07 PM] evov#0000
The reality is that prices have memory. People get used to something being worth a certain value and are comfortable continuing to sell at (or refusing to pay more than) what they're used to. To put it in perspective, my rea CX trade activity   (note, I'm not actively trying to sell it, I've been using it mostly )

{Attachments}
https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/1183249178156089374/1296655846259949589/image.png?ex=6814d19c&is=6813801c&hm=76e846b0959d4d07b0744c54997860c193bd6370c19d2194ded1ac4ad3a9ec99&


[17-Oct-24 09:09 PM] tanda#0000

What IS the true value of the item?

around 500-600 AIC per unit


[17-Oct-24 09:09 PM] tanda#0000
maaaybe as high as 800


[17-Oct-24 09:09 PM] evov#0000
Kinda depends on what brm is worth. Kind of depends how much is being made and how much demand there is for downstream products.


[17-Oct-24 09:10 PM] tanda#0000
well BRM costs 25 to make. Transport is the real killer. Cut out that and REA is cheap


[17-Oct-24 09:11 PM] tanda#0000

[17-Oct-24 09:11 PM] evov#0000
I guess renegades agree's with your thesis on REA pricing.


[17-Oct-24 09:11 PM] tanda#0000
shortages correct in time, but new demands generally stay


[17-Oct-24 09:12 PM] evov#0000
You're assuming the "old" price was "right" .. and that it wasn't undervalued at the time. Maybe the new price is the fair/reasonable point for it to be at.


[17-Oct-24 09:14 PM] tanda#0000
the only assumptions I made were honestly "I hope the price doesn't crash to 450/unit because then the margin is super tight"


[17-Oct-24 09:14 PM] tanda#0000
I looked at actual cost of production as a baseline for value rather than historic valuation


[17-Oct-24 09:17 PM] evov#0000
Rea is basically just for ships and sci consumables. So it's not exactly a super high volume item with unlimited demand. It's just a middle point between those demands and BRM production. People will repurpose existing CHP bases to make it IF it looks profitable for them AND they can get their hands on BRM.

And honestly, it's only really critical for ships... people with FER's will gladly just make ALE or GIN if Rea price is too high.


[17-Oct-24 09:19 PM] tanda#0000
I get it's niche, but it's also niche, easy to transport, not made in any bulk when it's not 800/unit, and has future demand expansions.


[17-Oct-24 09:19 PM] tanda#0000
I don't plan on cornering the market, but this will be an export operation soon

[19-Oct-24 04:50 PM] evov#0000
I think if it's only 1 CX, price spikes last less than a week because CX-CX shippers/traders will jump all over that margin like a fat kid on cake.

One of the major things I look at when anticipating a major shortage - volume. How much gets traded over a week, how much supply on the CX.

Roughly, 25k traded per week.  60k+ available on the CX. I might be wrong, but I wouldn't be too worried about anything other than a short term regional spike. If it does run dry I'll throw a few thousand up there.

XLOOKUP function - Microsoft Support
Use the XLOOKUP function when you need to find things in a table or a range by row. For example, look up the¬†price of an automotive part by the part number, or find an employee name based on their employee ID. With XLOOKUP, you can look in one column for a search term, and return a result from the same row in another column, regardless of which ...

[28-Oct-24 01:57 AM] laaxus#0000

[28-Oct-24 01:57 AM] laaxus#0000

[28-Oct-24 01:58 AM] laaxus#0000

[28-Oct-24 02:03 AM] evov#0000
Case by case imo. I find a lot of bid orders are just quicker and easier. I'm open to doing person to person deals, but it's hard to beat the ultra low time overhead that comes with putting up a bid order.


[28-Oct-24 02:05 AM] laaxus#0000

[28-Oct-24 02:05 AM] evov#0000

[28-Oct-24 02:10 AM] evov#0000
So while dealing person to person is great in theory - it's just not practical at higher volumes I think.


[28-Oct-24 02:20 AM] evov#0000
It looks like I'm going bankrupt in a hurry, but over that period my cash position dropped by about 85mil, I get cash via ship sales through private contracts and my warehouse stock position went up by . .  more than that. So it works out ok.


[28-Oct-24 02:50 AM] laaxus#0000
The good old d√©ficit spending strategy


[28-Oct-24 02:53 AM] evov#0000
It's moreso that CX activity and Contracts (person to person) ballance each other out. I'm a net Seller when it comes to person to person contracts, which makes me a net buyer on the CX.


[28-Oct-24 02:57 AM] evov#0000
Out of curiosity, is there actually much interest in filling big buy orders via contracts? I don't see that sort of thing listed too often so I just assume it's not really much of a thing.

[28-Oct-24 03:12 AM] evov#0000
nope. CX. The only private contracts I do at the moment are -
Ship Sales
Dmos initiative - ( Something I provide for some newer players where I'll supply the inputs + transport for free, and buy the outputs at a set price, paying now and picking up when it's done )


[28-Oct-24 03:14 AM] laaxus#0000

[28-Oct-24 03:15 AM] evov#0000
Yes. I aim to maintain a stockpile of about 100 days of operation for consumables / repairs.
Each week I'll update my stock list and go shopping on the CX as needed.


[28-Oct-24 03:15 AM] evov#0000
e.g.

{Attachments}
https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/1183249178156089374/1300372464928292895/image.png?ex=68147f3b&is=68132dbb&hm=bddec2e6885250dddc99146e9861709476be751152df276b0c11e06bc638e0ff&


[28-Oct-24 03:16 AM] evov#0000
So I don't need to worry about RAT since I've got more than I need. But I'll be actively buying DW if the price is right. If the price is (in my opinion) temporarily too high... I'll let it sit low for a while and buy up when it gets cheaper.


[28-Oct-24 03:17 AM] laaxus#0000
why not just put a bid order at the price you consider right ?


[28-Oct-24 03:17 AM] evov#0000
Because it just pointlessly soaks up capital to put bid orders up that won't get filled.

[28-Oct-24 03:21 AM] laaxus#0000

[28-Oct-24 03:22 AM] evov#0000

{Attachments}
https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/1183249178156089374/1300374135943331880/image.png?ex=681480c9&is=68132f49&hm=12d0bda0b4c5b871915cfc5571ebaa716d6c24d3f449b89de49ac6f206ec15a9&


[28-Oct-24 03:23 AM] evov#0000

[28-Oct-24 03:24 AM] evov#0000
DW is a bit deceptive on the numbers because I sold a ship in exchange for DW a while ago. So that topped up the DW storage tanks for a while üôÇ


[28-Oct-24 03:26 AM] finestone#0000
I came from Sim Companies where there is a tax on CX when posting so naturally personal contracts were better


[28-Oct-24 03:29 AM] evov#0000
The CX doesn't have a 'tax' exactly. But it does have a cost.
Personal contracts are typically instant. You agree on the trade, and it's done. 

CX Sales ( Red Ask orders ) - Your stock/capital sits there for some period of time.
CX Buys ( Green Bid orders ) - Your cash/capital sits there for some period of time.

Not a tax, but it's still a cost. Selling into (Green Bid Orders) - You don't waste capital because the trade is instant... but you eat the lower cost. Same in reverse when buying from (Red Ask orders)


[28-Oct-24 03:32 AM] finestone#0000
That is certainly true! I think a small tax when posting sell orders would be nice to avoid the "Crazy high price posting for storage" it would also cause a deflationary force. Though in this conversion you were already discussing the dislike of people not using the CX more so maybe this game isn't quite ready for that yet.


[28-Oct-24 03:33 AM] evov#0000
Local markets is the other point of trade that people don't really talk about much.


[28-Oct-24 03:33 AM] finestone#0000
True i wish more people used LM


[28-Oct-24 03:34 AM] laaxus#0000
I would use LM if they were cx with limited comodity trade


[28-Oct-24 03:34 AM] finestone#0000
LM is kind of a pain to use though they need to make them like mini CX i think


[28-Oct-24 03:34 AM] laaxus#0000
LM could be a popi, and each level would give another commodity that could be traded


[28-Oct-24 03:34 AM] evov#0000
On the set of planets I'm developing now - I'm aiming to keep LM fee's and Warehouse fee's at zero if possible. I think on planet trade via LM's is a net win if used properly.


[28-Oct-24 03:35 AM] finestone#0000
All good points i like using personal cons for better deals and supporting someone that i routinally work with, that being said i try to use the CX as much as possible


[28-Oct-24 03:37 AM] evov#0000
Yea, they've all got costs. Personal contracts are good financially, they just (in my experience) have a lot higher cognitive cost. You spend more time/energy dealing with them to get the same volume of goods traded compared to using the CX.

{Reactions}
üíØ 

[28-Oct-24 03:42 AM] laaxus#0000

Just because


[28-Oct-24 03:43 AM] laaxus#0000
the CX is best to find out what is the correct price at the current moment


[28-Oct-24 06:21 AM] realharvey#0000
The reason why "CX"-Trading isnt happening a lot is mostly because of the low player count we have currently and how long it takes for the market to correct itself. There is not a lot of Commodities on the CX that you can really rely on to plan your bases.

When I consider planning a base, I always take into Account: What can I take from the CX to save myself some permits and what do I have to vertically integrate myself? A lot of it comes down to: I have to integrate it myself otherwise the market will explode in prices because there is no supply. 

You could argue that if I do create that demand, supply will catch up. Which is true. But it takes way to long for it to do so. People that have cheap permits don't have the capital, to quickly setup a base to satisfy that demand and established players have to high permit costs to make that supply shortage worth their while.

Another thing is: People chase high profit bases when planning their bases and consider less how their base will impact the CX dynamic of all commodities that arre involved in it. This leads to almost no one increasing the supply of a commodity because that would only lead to 50k profit per day.

So what is the takeaway from it? I do believe that with growing player numbers the CX will become more and more attractive and the amount of commoodities you can savely rely on there will increase with time.


[28-Oct-24 06:26 AM] evov#0000
I have noticed the materials I can count on the CX to supply has steadily grown over the months/years.

I remember a point when I was setting up for making Afabs, where I felt the need to make my own CL, and EPO, and NR, and TCL and KV etc. Now . . . most of those things are available in sufficient qty's on the CX that it's not mandatory to make it yourself.


[28-Oct-24 06:56 AM] pxlfox.#0000
It sounds to me, that a central forum, where the current market state (demand, supply, development) is discussed, could benefit new and old players and help Antares as a region to grow in a more organised way.

Stating what materials need to have more supply, would give new players with available permits an incentive to expand into those fields.

Older players have often a more broader view on how different materials are interconnected, can better determine what markets need to be stocked up, and maybe even have the funds to further stimulate growth by funding new players into needed fields.


[28-Oct-24 06:59 AM] pxlfox.#0000
After all, this is a game, so a more developed and stable market is beneficial to the whole player base. There is no real benefit to keep secrets and making ‚Äúbig bucks‚Äù, since there is nothing really to ‚Äúwin‚Äù.


[28-Oct-24 07:06 AM] pxlfox.#0000

Something like that.

[29-Oct-24 01:28 AM] evov#0000
The problem with the CX snapshots.. is that it gives a lot of very precise information about volumes, but it's very misleading about it's accuracy. You can see in very fine detail how much volume is on the market, how much is moving etc.... but you have zero idea of how much is sitting in people's warehouses or being traded privately.

There are several items where I have a lot more of it in my warehouse than exists across all the CX's. And I'm reasonably confident that there's more than 10 other people who could say the same.


[29-Oct-24 03:18 AM] realharvey#0000
When it comes to the CX there will always be problems. People with Capital can always mess with things and you can end every analysis with: But a big boy with capital could ruin all your thoughts.

[03-Nov-24 05:43 PM] sidepipe#0000
If I was to calculate it, I‚Äôd basically just do 12 hour intervals - I only fly my ships in the morning and evening anyway. So each base needs resupplied every 10 days, you figure out how many ships each base takes and choose a reasonable value for how long the trips take. I assume you‚Äôd end up with an answer pretty much the same as the gut feeling approach, which is why I haven‚Äôt done it üòÑ


[03-Nov-24 05:47 PM] tanda#0000
I agree with the 12 hour thing. In the morning, ships need to be in before 5am, and between 4 and 9pm for turn around


[03-Nov-24 08:29 PM] evov#0000
r.e. Ship count -

When I feel comfortable just sending ships out once per day (24 hr intervals) ... I've got enough. If I feel like I need to jump on before work to take advantage of any of those 12 hour flight times... I'll think about making more.

Any spare shipping capacity I've got gets split between 
- sitting idle at the ANT cx - ready to leap into action when needed.
- flights that don't make sense logistically, but cognitively make life easier ( sending out near empty ships to resolve "now" type issues, without caring enough to fill them up )
- cx-cx trading
- renting them out via shipping contracts whenever a friend puts up a bat signal and needs help.
