[09-Nov-24 04:38 PM] evov#0000
Disagree. INS ran out in BEN while there were plenty of BID's active. C skyrocketed in ANT while there were plenty of BID's active.

I use bids a lot, but it's tangential to the issue.

The core of the issue of items running out is that too many people are trying to use "Just in time" logistics and not keeping enough of a buffer on hand.

RL examples of this occurred during the Covid period where plenty of business' / industries saw similar issues. All of a sudden supply of critical parts could take weeks or months instead of days, which would then cause downstream delays of higher order products.

The solution for the most part - increasing buffers and being a little bit less "lean". While supply was certain, "Just in time" manufacturing logistics was "the way" - it was the most cost effective way to make stuff, and while supply was certain and consistent it worked great.

Having increased buffers allows the price to rise more gradually without supply dropping to zero. It affords more time for people to recognise there's a shortage and spin up new industry to supply into that shortage. When buffer size is too small it's like - Things are FINE, FINE, FINE, FINE, that's a bit expensive, OH shit the market is all out of X and my factories are now idle shit shit shit reeeeeeer <insert blame problem on other people instead of blaming myself for not having enough of a buffer>


[09-Nov-24 04:39 PM] tanda#0000
we're talking about two different things


[09-Nov-24 04:40 PM] tanda#0000
I'm talking about lightly populated markets that have very little to no traffic. If I'm both selling and buying in that market it helps 1)attract buyers who will use that product 2) attract producers who may otherwise have never produced that product


[09-Nov-24 04:41 PM] tanda#0000
I've seen it help take off the SFK, GC and THP markets just a little bit


[09-Nov-24 04:46 PM] tanda#0000
You might be trying to reply to Laaxus' statements regarding bids. I was specifically intending to state that bids are only ever a long term solution, they don't help in short term crises


[09-Nov-24 04:51 PM] evov#0000
For spooling up new markets - bids and asks on the cx play equally important roles imo.
I think the core of the issue in a lot of those markets though, is that you get a lot of items only get used in 1 production. So it requires a 1 to 1 production line and it just doesn't make a lot of sense to either spool up markets for the products or to lean on the CX for them.

( And yeah - to me it looked like a continuation of the "C market running dry" line of thought" - is what I thought I was commenting on sorry )


[09-Nov-24 04:52 PM] tanda#0000

[09-Nov-24 05:27 PM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
Steam version got recently broken on Linux.. Me sad. üò≠


[09-Nov-24 06:27 PM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
I would almost entirely agree with this sentiment... However, give me the chance to expound on this, by bringing all of it into some abstraction.

Lets say, if you're focused on the short-term realities of what you do, then you could have an "operational" mindset --- short term objectives, be they from day-to-day, towards week-to-week:

* You don't have any structure regarding what you intend to achieve in-game; you're always "reacting" to a given FIO/APEX market situation in any market region, and you may have organised some metrics, but such is dis-jointed, distracted, or generally not becoming of a joint-strategic effort, with your own means, towards some specific goal.

Short-term ASK/BID operations fall into this category, along with short-term production goals. Macro-economic strategies will not pivot based on these in-game actions, but all other micro-economic strategies will.


[09-Nov-24 06:29 PM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
The inverse of this is a "structural" mindset --- long term objectives, be they from month-to-month, or towards year-to-year:

* You have planned out serious, long-term structural investments, which you intend not only to invest in-game, but to achieve them through an attrition through time. You're not really reacting on any FIO/APEX market situation, since you have your bases covered, and are only really having to deal with your "retail" market operations on the CX.

All other considerations are handled with your own permits, your own logistics, your own partnerships, or whatever else can be had, since you're no-longer on an "Input-based" operational metric, but on an "Output-based" structural metric.

Macro-economic strategies will pivot based on this... If you can out-produce a competitor, on a better break even-price... If your competitor doesn't pivot, then they will eventually break.


[09-Nov-24 06:35 PM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
I suspect that everyone is within the range of these two disparate means of in-game activity. If you're not, then it would be my recommendation to consider the #other-half?

-----

I hope that my edits are making my ideas more readable to everyone. If you want less, well god'darn, now y'all are asking for som'real hill-billy talk.

[10-Nov-24 05:45 AM] evov#0000
If you want to track YOUR GROWTH - you should probably not include the value of assets that are given to you. Such as those bases. Otherwise, you'll get a very unrealistic view on how you're doing. When the slope of the graph is primarily determined by the types of bases people gift you, and not by the production + market activity you do... it's not really a reflection of anything other than the points in time you took leased base deals.


[10-Nov-24 05:46 AM] evov#0000
I think the sort of info you're looking for.... you really need to subtract debts/loans/value of leased bases etc from it. That way it shows the net sum of your actual earnings.


[10-Nov-24 05:49 AM] evov#0000
Also using the log scale - I can imagine those 2 things combined, 2 months from now you'll be looking at it wondering why it feels like you're not getting the forward movement you might expect.

So what if instead of having a narrow one day window for ideal repairs every whatever period, resources were just consumed ‚Äúdaily‚Äù like workforce consumables instead?  Any...

[12-Nov-24 07:20 AM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
Well, if this idea would make you feel better, I just ship in full production building construction mats to my bases. I repair every 45 days usually (it's not a strict rule for me). You get insufficient sums when your operation is like at day 135 -> 180, or less, due to things like BTA/LTA, or whatever buildings require only like 1 unit for the repairs. It's a ratio thing.

Around that time, I just ship back the leftovers, and bring back a fresh stock. It's turns the issue from repairs every 45-> 90 days, to every 6 months or so. I have the capital to sustain this, and the storage.


[12-Nov-24 07:22 AM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
I think PMMG extended also has semi-automated inventory transfer functions that will do most of that routine, and annoying work for you, once you set it up. Don't ask me how they work, as I haven't fiddled with them yet.

I have my own custom Burn sheets that keeps tracks of my materials for repairs. I set it to "Top off" rather than provision because I don't want to overstock too much on repair materials.

[12-Nov-24 10:10 AM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
Oh, yeah I think I might have found an immediate feature pitch to the repair issue...

Just add a few 0's to the production outputs of any fabs/construction materials, and then divide their MAT t/m3 metrics by that same base 10 figure, and edit everyone's CX/INV entries by the same multiple and divide their prices by the same multiple, and all other linkages or whatnot. 

Degradation/repair estimates are actually fractional (look to current MCG figures, because it's easily evidenced, due to higher #s), but since current fab figures are basically in the single digits, this results in discrete cut-off points for repairs, due to ratios and funky math.


[12-Nov-24 10:11 AM] jcheung#0000
It's not fractional, it's ceiling


[12-Nov-24 10:11 AM] jcheung#0000
Any unused is voided


[12-Nov-24 10:12 AM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
It's cuz they round up. So you need 1.1 ABHs to repair, but they only come in single digit increments, so it's 2 ABHs to repair fully.


[12-Nov-24 10:15 AM] jcheung#0000
Aka, ceiling


[12-Nov-24 10:16 AM] jcheung#0000
Not fractional


[12-Nov-24 10:16 AM] jcheung#0000

AML uses 30 UPK/day/week

[13-Nov-24 02:38 AM] evov#0000
I'm not sure I actually understand the issues people have with current repair mechanics.

Do people feel like the cognitive load is too high?  - I feel like repairs are lower cognitive load than workforce consumables.

Do people not like the crossover points... i.e. feeling like if they miss a breakpoint of 45/60/90 days they're somehow losing out on a massive amount of profit? - Of the people concerned about this, have you actually looked at the cost per item produced difference between each of those repair intervals? Have you looked at how that compares to the cost of lost production efficiency?

[13-Nov-24 05:28 AM] jcheung#0000
Yes. Less waste, simpler for people to do intuitively.
For consumables i can go "i maintain this stockpile target."
For repairs, if i don't have third party tools and knowledge, i would have to know that repair costs round up to the next whole, and any extra is wasted, (the following two parts are not the parts that annoys me as this work has already been done, but it applies to anyone who doesn't have access to third party tools) i then have to record the cost of repairs each day over a long period, say 100 or 200 days, then calculate the cost breakpoints and productivity losses to get a handful of specific dates where repair would cost the least. Then i have to be online and active on one of those specific dates, and if i miss it because i forgot about it, well, have to wait for the next period which is usually a month away.
I can't schedule maintenance so that it takes automatically on that date chosen
I can't nist have a stockpile for my maintenance personnel to work out of
No, i have to be present for the repair and it has to be initiated by me, at the time of repair start, and any excesses are wasted


[13-Nov-24 05:29 AM] jcheung#0000
There's a few different ways that i would be satisfied with it


[13-Nov-24 05:29 AM] jcheung#0000
Among which would be allowing me to pre-queue the repair days or weeks in advance


[13-Nov-24 05:30 AM] evov#0000
Ok I think I understand your perspective a bit better. It's about the fact that there's a "therotical optimal" time to repair, and you feel like you're being punished by doing it wrong. And doing it wrong is very easy to do because there's a lot of hoops to jump through to figure out what the optimal is... and then further hoops to jump through to put that optimal plan into action?


[13-Nov-24 05:30 AM] jcheung#0000
In short, yes


[13-Nov-24 05:31 AM] jcheung#0000
Plus if you were to make the repair costs more passive, you can introduce breakdowns which randomly degrade lines a point or two


[13-Nov-24 05:32 AM] evov#0000
I think it's mis-placed anxiety. I don't think the difference between getting it perfect, vs getting it wrong, is as big as people are concerned that it is.

Give me an example of one of your planets - The planet, a bui you have there, something you produce out of it etc. And I'll print out the production cost differences that different repair timings have on it if you like.


[13-Nov-24 05:33 AM] evov#0000
The tldr of it - I suspect - is that low tier goods built on high teir planets (TSH/HSE etc) will be punished a bit. Everything else won't be much of a concern.

[13-Nov-24 06:10 AM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
I suppose that I don't have to drop screenies, but this one I've dropped before on UFO. 

When I was going through my own growth pains, I just chose to do a top-down approach, modelling for simplicity, and pure retention of daily production realities on my bases. I looked into the publicly posted functions...

 I could have chosen 90 day repairs, or 30 day repairs, but for the buildings that I predominantly use, a 45 day repair period was chosen since the building MAT ratios basically fit the bill that I was looking for.

In keeping with that, I have retained a 99.6% efficiency with say Prunplanner metrics, and my weekly I/O requirements are basically unaffected. If I kept to say 90 day repairs, I'd have a 96% efficiency, losing 3.5 days out of every 90, and I would definitely notice the I/O stuff when I got close to say 70 days from last repairs.

{Attachments}
https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/1183249178156089374/1306229648677535815/this.png?ex=6814b628&is=681364a8&hm=cdfd51466afad034df496e998e80e880f24fee44288c3a5965c8ebb92c52cf7c&


[13-Nov-24 06:13 AM] evov#0000
I used to use 90 day repair cycles for everything because it was less strain on logistics... and ships are expensive.

I'm less concerned with shipping constraints now.... so I do 60 days.

[19-Nov-24 11:08 AM] pxlfox.#0000
I know it was mentioned somewhere, but I can't find it. 
How much do buildings degrade per day? 
E.g. I have `x` construction materials, that cost `y` - how much of it degrades per day?


[19-Nov-24 11:09 AM] pxlfox.#0000
I'm finding formulas for building costs and efficiency, but not the daily degradation rate


[19-Nov-24 11:16 AM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
It's an inverse logistic curve. Let me give you a picture with explanation and a link.


[19-Nov-24 11:17 AM] pxlfox.#0000
isn't the degradtion linear? The efficency is not, but the repair costs should be, aren't them?


[19-Nov-24 11:20 AM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
Formulae: You can run the calculations on a single-column sheet, then run a difference between each to show you the delta between each day. No it's not linear. https://pct.fnar.net/building-degradation/index.html

Degradation rates are a two step calculation. 1) Calculating the delta (difference) per day, which translates to a **ratio of days old**, from day established. 2) Those figures should give you good metrics on what you'd want to repair with, as repair costs are always whole numbers, and the repair BRAs always round up.

Picture is over 180 days, after which your buildings just don't degrade.

{Attachments}
https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/1183249178156089374/1308481937660448879/this.png?ex=6814fec4&is=6813ad44&hm=0fcb1aa23b159713f000e91ba75add20d050f1aa98a0e1395a6ae8a13a4219af&

{Embed}
https://pct.fnar.net/building-degradation/index.html
Building Degradation - PrUn Community Derived Information
Condition Formula Condition = 0.67 / (1 + e^((1789/25000) * (DaysSinceLastRepair - C))) + 0.33
C is either 100.87 or 107.87.
There is speculation that the additional 7 days for C is a bug as it happens inconsistently.
Repair costs and reclaimables Repair cost is determined by:
RepairCost = BuildingCost - ReclaimableCost
ReclaimableCost is determ...


[19-Nov-24 11:21 AM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
Your condition % in your BBS buffer is not a "repair" value. It's a building productivity value, which gets plugged into your PROD queues, for daily cycles (efficiency).


[19-Nov-24 11:22 AM] pxlfox.#0000
what's the green line representing in your diagram?


[19-Nov-24 11:23 AM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
Nothing?


[19-Nov-24 11:29 AM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
Take a look at MoonSugar's sheet. It's basically a step-by-step walk through of what I said. My stuff ain't straightforward, as it's an intuitive approach. https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ELsfw4ii1hQFWDd-BL4JzwqHc-wGVXbJtvAeprv0pZ0/edit?gid=0#gid=0

We've got this recorded in #prun-resources


[19-Nov-24 11:30 AM] pxlfox.#0000
I worked through the resources you linked above ^^


[19-Nov-24 11:32 AM] pxlfox.#0000
The repair costs (amount of materials needed to repair something) is *technically* linear, but since you can't repair 0.234 BBH (less then one), it "ticks" up, as the guide explains. I was looking for 1/180 (or ~0.0055555), which is the rate buildings degrade per day.

[21-Nov-24 04:30 AM] evov#0000
tldr -< New project I've been focusing on - Area 151 - has 3 planets currently open for new members. IA-151 B (Electronics), IA-151 D (Chemistry) and IA-151 E (Metallurgy ) If anyone's interested in joining onto these planets, hit me up. >


- Area 151 - Open for recruitment -
For the last month or two, most of my spare resources in the game have been dedicated towards getting this project off the ground, and I feel like the time has come to make it a bit more public and open it up for broader involvement from the Antare's (and potentially Hortus ) community.

The goal of the project is to build up an industrial hub in a location well suited to the placement of future gateways. I've set up 5 planets ( IA-151 a/b/c/d/e ) with cogc's for Construction / Electronics / Manufacturing / Chemistry and Metallurgy. The intent with the project is to charge higher than normal taxes (mostly on the higher tier pops) and to use the combined tax base of all the planets in the project to fund the construction of gateways. 

The hope, is that having this mix of CoGC planets in the same system, less than a day's flight from ANT and less than a day's flight from HRT, will provide benefits in terms of logistics, potential collaboration and availability of higher teir pop, that exceeds the cost of the extra taxes.

We have base establishment fee's on the planets, but it's not something we expect anyone to actually pay, they're just there to make sure that only people who are aligned with the broader goals of the project put bases down on the planets. It also allows us to better control the influx of population demand, so we can run immigration programs specifically for each person when they join to help reduce waiting time between joining and getting their population filled.

At the moment, we have inactive Immigration programs ( and as a result an opening for a new base ) on the following planets.
IA-151 B (Electronics)
IA-151 D (Chemistry)
IA-151 E (Metallurgy)

If anyone's interested in joining Area 151, or if you have any questions, hit me up.

[23-Nov-24 11:10 PM] antisyntax#0000

[23-Nov-24 11:11 PM] tanda#0000
I honestly doubt it. For a game this niche, it is unlikely that they'll upgrade their servers much further. Even a couple basic trading scripts would likely be able to crash the server easily


[23-Nov-24 11:11 PM] antisyntax#0000
you think?


[23-Nov-24 11:11 PM] antisyntax#0000
Just from the increased activity, or...?


[23-Nov-24 11:12 PM] tanda#0000
Just from the volume of demands such scripts would be able to pass to the server. We currently already have issues and memory leaks infrequently (we are in early access after all). But the devs already kinda took their stance on "nothing automated can pass commands to the server"


[23-Nov-24 11:12 PM] antisyntax#0000
aww oaky


[23-Nov-24 11:12 PM] tanda#0000
Which I really don't expect them to deviate much from (and yeah they can really bog down a server easily)

[23-Nov-24 11:13 PM] tanda#0000

[28-Nov-24 12:27 AM] evov#0000
People (especially newer players) very heavily under-estimate the cost of providing logistics (ships) to run their bases.

This is a list I made showing the capital cost of ships required to cover each process. ( real costs will vary depending on flight times/fuel use )

If you're short on ships, stay away from the top of the list, lean into the bottom of the list imo.

{Attachments}
https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/1183249178156089374/1311579228428308520/image.png?ex=68150e98&is=6813bd18&hm=305cad543c0f8cb4e3c194829c27245f68714822befab35ce7bd95908ab5b5ea&

{Reactions}
üëç (2)

[29-Nov-24 06:27 PM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
It is good to see that our that our in-house #bankers are making good use of my tools. (FYI : an updated sheet was dropped via https://discord.com/channels/1183243037430796339/1247251299620225087/1307774936060002304 , which fixed a few bugs).

There are two ways to increase your daily ROIs...

1) Increase the #thickness of the loans. (I.e. more money dolled out for HQ/ship/buffer upgrades).

2) Increase the #length of the loans. (I.e. more terms, up to the max that can be had via in-game CONTD buffers --- **stable** and **annuity** type loans are actually compounding in nature, whereas **interest** loans are simple interest, over the loan term. --- glhf?)

[02-Dec-24 09:26 AM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
But... The overall architecture of in-game economic/production I/Os is definitely not helping... You've usually got your outputs following a hierarchical method of production from lower tiers --> higher tiers... And even when you get to those higher tiers, the applications are incredibly niche. (basically only shipbuilding, high tier POPI upgrades, and HQ fabs, across all connected industries)...

This is also underlies the basic consumables, across all tiers, which are usually locked behind higher processes..


[02-Dec-24 09:26 AM] marat_sh#0000
major problem with vertical integration is lack of BIDs


[02-Dec-24 09:26 AM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
Farming / Food Industries has a nice mix though. Many basic things get cycled through a PIO workforce, and the rest (even if they require TECs to get the inputs), are then cycled in through SETs, for the final retail products. Other things are much worse... AML/ASM loops? PIOs for extraction/smelting, and then straight to TEC/ENGs for refinement, and then back to say TECs for final retail production.

[02-Dec-24 10:14 AM] marat_sh#0000
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparative_advantage

{Embed}
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparative_advantage
Comparative advantage
Comparative advantage in an economic model is the advantage over others in producing a particular good. A good can be produced at a lower relative opportunity cost or autarky price, i.e. at a lower relative marginal cost prior to trade. Comparative advantage describes the economic reality of the gains from trade for individuals, firms, or nation...

[07-Dec-24 03:48 PM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
Yeah. Most of the starter planets have a revolving-door phenomenon with their plot figures. Most of the people on them are TRIALs (like 80-->90%). They're quickly kicked out once they lose interest in the game and no longer log in regularly. It'll be the third time I've seen Deimos being open/closed to non-starter colonists, since like ~1 or ~1.5 years ago.

[13-Dec-24 09:36 AM] sidepipe#0000
There‚Äôs basically two levers that the IDC/EDC affect the economy through - driving up the cost of SCI / ENG upkeep, and introducing more money into the system. The first indirectly increases prices for everything else because it drives demand for upkeep items, fabs, etc. The second is inflation and is basically magic to me. But if we‚Äôre concluding that the point of those MMs is to drive growth in the economy by being an infinite money pit (which is sort of what I‚Äôve settled on), wouldn‚Äôt it make more sense if it used more stuff, and did so more directly?

{Reactions}
üíØ

[13-Dec-24 10:25 AM] sidepipe#0000
From a player perspective, I want the game to reward me for moving up the supply chain and making more advanced things (and that's because I personally find the production more interesting than making money). But there are huge parts of the tech / production tree of the game that just have very limited demand eventhough they have MMs because they're just so much less profitable than IDC. The rational choice for me is to convert most / all of my bases to IDC and just rake in that cash forever. But I think it would be good for the economy of the game to more strongly encourage making those complicated items, because for AIR / LOG / Ship Part you make, there's so many inputs that you basically can't do it on your own. You need to choose a point to stop making extra bases and just buy goods from the market

[13-Dec-24 10:46 AM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
Well I think the MM bids were supposed to be a way for people to clear out inventories on some of the more complex POPI upgrade/upkeep materials, since running those BUIs without an adequate market is harsh on your ROIs and weekly revenues... 

But once the fab/consumable markets for those higher end processes became more available/cheaper, and people realised just how minimal work those EDC/IDC were for the returns... 

(not ROI metrics, but capital turnover, or huge capital investments, which then churn out much higher permit revenue metrics than basic processes),...

then it sorta got out of control imo... (fyi we're looking at a doubling of global currencies in circulation, from 01-2024, to 12-2024) üò¢

[13-Dec-24 02:13 PM] evov#0000
I think there's 2 completely separate lines of thought people are going down.  1. Are zero input MM's good vs bad for the game.   2. Are zero input MM's good vs bad for WINNING at the game.

Unless anyone here is a Dev, 1. seems somewhat irrelevant.

Ultimately, EDC/IDC farms are somewhat immune from "attack". I've tried. And it's a fruitless endeavor. The only way to diminish their relative strength, is to inflate the rest of the economy to match their profitability ( or convince Dev's to continue nerfing them ). Having more people make EDC/IDC's, seems to me to be the shortest path on both those failure modes.

They make good $/base numbers, but their RoI isn't great. If you're constrained by #permits - IDC's make a lot of sense. If you're constrained by $$ they're not that great of an idea.

{Reactions}
üíØ

[28-Dec-24 11:28 AM] jcheung#0000
Oh no


[28-Dec-24 11:29 AM] jcheung#0000
....i learned of a cool zero trust secret santa thing


[28-Dec-24 11:29 AM] jcheung#0000
Is kinda neat


[28-Dec-24 11:30 AM] jvaler#0000
?


[28-Dec-24 11:32 AM] jcheung#0000
It's a way of doing secret santa with nobody knowing the pairs except for the gift giver, not even the organizer


[28-Dec-24 11:33 AM] jvaler#0000
right, what's the way?


[28-Dec-24 11:36 AM] jcheung#0000
You define an order for people to go in
Each person, in order, writes down a pair of numbers
When last is finished, first gets list. Scrambles order. Shifts second half down by one. Swaps the second half of their code with a new number.
Each person can choose to shift down one, or not. Then swap their code with new number.
Last person does not get to shift down, just swap their number
Back to first. Swap first half of code with name. Repeat for all.
List can be publicly posted at this point, i think


[28-Dec-24 11:37 AM] jcheung#0000
Name is the giftee, code is the gifter


[28-Dec-24 11:39 AM] tanda#0000
I think I need a math degree to apply this concept


[28-Dec-24 11:40 AM] jvaler#0000
üòµ‚Äçüí´


[28-Dec-24 11:40 AM] jcheung#0000
Well


[28-Dec-24 11:40 AM] jcheung#0000
Take it in steps lol


[28-Dec-24 11:40 AM] jcheung#0000
Granted if one person screws it up, it all breaks


[28-Dec-24 11:43 AM] jcheung#0000
Basically all you need is 3 numbers that identify yourself to you


[28-Dec-24 11:44 AM] jcheung#0000
Then you find the correct id each time you get the list and replace the correct part with another thing


[28-Dec-24 12:03 PM] laaxus#0000
I have an easier one


[28-Dec-24 12:03 PM] laaxus#0000
Everybody put its name in a bol


[28-Dec-24 12:04 PM] laaxus#0000
Then everybody pick a name, randomly


[28-Dec-24 12:04 PM] laaxus#0000
If it's its own, you repick


[28-Dec-24 12:04 PM] laaxus#0000
If you're the last one, we redo the whole drawing

[30-Dec-24 02:51 PM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
Ohh it's over? Geez.. I was gonna start to root for the guy, since they we're gonna lose in the long term anyways....

That sort of market fixing does work, you just have to be like lowstrife, and provide BUY.CX orders, at margin, against the ASK.CX orders. 

Anything you get sold, you just funnel into the ASK.CX bids you got, which are in-line with everyone else. Huge buy-outs + relists will always fail, unless you're actually going to use the stuff purchased.

[31-Dec-24 10:14 AM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
If anyone's going to pivot to RG... I'd suggest to get into negotiations with anyone who's needing a constant supply of RG, or GL, among other things.

It's one thing to "claim" that a market is running out, with a weak advert on anything in hopes of "boosting" productivity.... It's another thing to offer tangible sales turnovers, to anyone who might think of spinning up a base for the stuff. 

Don't let your fellow Antareans dry out on the surplus markets. Negotiate with each other, and purchase what others are making, or could make.


[31-Dec-24 10:16 AM] tanda#0000
Cmon Roh. It's me we're talking about here


[31-Dec-24 10:33 AM] scintillating_iridescence#0000
;P

It's not about you, it's about the commodity market. RG is very niche, being used for LC/WS (SCI consumables), shipbuilding, or POPI upkeep/upgrades... and nothing else. 

If you know your weekly metrics, then you can pitch an advertisement in-house. Anyone with a spare permit should be keen, as a Metallurgy COGC, GF base (for GL/RG+), is an easy revenue/upkeep stream. However they just need the sales turnover, which they're unlikely to get at the CX.

[05-Jan-25 03:49 AM] random_di5cord_user#0000
If you disable the top bar buttons in rprun they use the default alphanumeric sort order so you can just put numbers at the beginning of their names.

I don't know if they keep that order if you turn it back on but they might

{Reactions}
üëç 

[05-Jan-25 03:52 AM] random_di5cord_user#0000
I am told they also use the same order as the top bar so if you hade enough of them so both the ones you want are on the top bar you can reorder them there and then unhide


[05-Jan-25 03:55 AM] random_di5cord_user#0000
The setting to disable it is screen-tab-bar (in XIT SET FEAT) 

Reenabling it, however, restores the bad sort.

(This sorting issue was about the only feature of rprun that I needed to get rid of immediately, so I'm glad I didn't use it long enough to want the top buttons)

{Reactions}
üëç

[28-Jan-25 12:20 AM] evov#0000
On a semi related note, I've been on the lookout for my next "project" to work on in the game. One of the idea's that made the shortlist was to start up some MM operations for the ANT CX. Similar to what lowstrife does for/to the MOR CX. 

For the most part in the game, I've been focused on production capacity. Building long logistic chains to solo produce complicated items ( afabs, then ships, now gateway gates ). While I intend for that to remain a core part of what I do in the game, I'm looking to branch out into something new and the MM game seemed like one possibility. 

Before doing it though, I just wanted to throw the idea up here to get thoughts/feedback from people. Do people think it would be a net benefit to the ANT community? Would it "feel bad" to look at the CX and feel like an individual was in control of or manipulating certain markets, or would increased supply / stability /liquidity on the ANT CX feel good and make it easier to do business in the region?

{Attachments}
https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/1183249178156089374/1333683140975132672/themarket.jpg?ex=68150cf7&is=6813bb77&hm=c5fdb3343a344772b66350d2b75fa8e0b5bdc098831e004cc643e64b516a8a07&

[28-Jan-25 09:20 AM] archielvahr#0000
The most important role of MPs is to take over if the governor goes missing. Especially on small planets. On big planets with 4 MPs + a governor.. it's just backup insurance.


[28-Jan-25 09:21 AM] archielvahr#0000
But yeah, if the governor forgets the COGC or something, make sure it gets filled

[29-Jan-25 11:08 PM] evov#0000
I started a couple planets  nearly 2 years ago to test it out and see what it was like. I founded FK-794c and FK-794d as a HYF planet and an FP planet next to Boucher.

I started those planets without an admin center... because at the time that was quite expensive for me. I found it took WAAY too long for pop to fill, especially Settlers.

The 9 I've started recently, all start with Admin Center / CogC / Warehouse (2k space) and Local Market. Pop infrastructure up to whatever you plan on supporting. That combo (assuming pop inf up to Engineers) is about 8mil. +4mil if you want to support scientists. 

While it's time consuming - fractional upkeep on the pop requirements is good way to save $ week to week. 
Immigration programs are life.

[01-Feb-25 01:18 PM] manhim#0000

{Reactions}
üëÜ 

[01-Feb-25 01:18 PM] manhim#0000
But yeah, profit need to be considered, but there are lots of strategies. Like optimizing logistics.


[01-Feb-25 01:25 PM] sidepipe#0000
Yeah, early on margins are super important because you wanna turn your 100k AIC into 150k AIC as fast as possible. Later on, that shifts because money is much less of a limitation, so if you can invest 200k at a 50% margin, or 1.5M at a 20% margin, it's better to choose the second one because you make more money even though it's less capital efficient. At least, that's how I like to think about it


[01-Feb-25 01:26 PM] sidepipe#0000
As you get larger, it's less about earning the best return on your limited investment, and more about earning _any_ return on as much of your money as possible


[01-Feb-25 01:26 PM] realharvey#0000
Well in that case ROI of a base with a recipe is still way more worth than actual Margin. üòÖ


[01-Feb-25 01:27 PM] manhim#0000
Yeah, I've been building up my inventories from 14 to 21 days on all my bases and I haven't been able to build a new base with my own money in 7 weeks üòÖ


[01-Feb-25 01:27 PM] tanda#0000
my third most profitable base runs an 18% margin


[01-Feb-25 01:29 PM] sidepipe#0000
I'm kinda in a similar situation - as profits go up, margins tend to go down (ignore the bottom 5 bases, some of them are getting rebuilt / resupplied üòÑ )

[01-Feb-25 01:43 PM] evov#0000
imo, the 2 numbers that make the most sense when looking at the "value" of a base.

1. RoI - How long does it take to generate profits equal to the cost of the base.
2. $ / Area / Day - How much profit per day can I make from the use of the permit.

There is tension between these two numbers. Generally... the lower tier / cheaper bases have better RoI, but worse $/Area/Day. Higher tier bases will earn more $ for your permit, but cost a lot more to set up.

Which number makes more sense to use, depends on the cost of your next permit. As a really rough guide - I would say if you're <20 permits - focus on RoI -  As you get more than 20 permits - Start looking more closely at $/Area/Day. Once you're 30+ permits, you no longer care what the cost of the base is to set up because your permits will cost more than double whatever base you might want to build.

{Reactions}
üíØ 

[01-Feb-25 01:54 PM] manhim#0000

[01-Feb-25 03:06 PM] pxlfox.#0000

[01-Feb-25 03:08 PM] pxlfox.#0000

[01-Feb-25 03:10 PM] pxlfox.#0000
it kinda is - margin and ROI are great, except the actual profit is relatively small (mostly around 50k a day)


[01-Feb-25 03:10 PM] pxlfox.#0000

[01-Feb-25 03:11 PM] pxlfox.#0000

[01-Feb-25 03:18 PM] manhim#0000

[01-Feb-25 03:20 PM] pxlfox.#0000
I take shipping costs as the actual amount you have to pay to transport the materials from A to B (fuel + repairs)
Shipping capacity is what my company effectively can transport in a period of time, mostly limited by the amount of ships I have or vacant space on other ships on that route

[03-Feb-25 12:59 AM] evov#0000
Got my first HCB (5k5k cargo bay) rolling off the line in 1day, 10hrs. So, about 2 days from now I'll have a 5k5k ship available to sell.

I've had a number of people wanting to pre-buy them, or put orders in for the ships before they're built. But that's not how I roll. So I'm trying to figure out how I should sell/distribute the first few of these in-demand prestige (at the moment) ships. Looking for thoughts ideas on any of the following.

A. Public auction - Open up for bids each time a ship rolls off the line. Highest bid in a 24hr window gets the ship. (Seems kinda interesting and fun)

B. Change (increase) the price until the demand for the ship matches my capacity to supply. (The free market maximalist in me thinks this makes sense as I worship at the altar of supply and demand)

C. Hold to what I expect my long term pricing to be, but prioritize access to ships based on my level of interaction with people in game. i.e. people that are part of my projects or that I regularly colaborate with. ( Most likely first purchase options will go to people who joined me in the IA project )

D. Avoid the drama and just make them for myself until the market levels out and other suppliers are also meeting demand.

[03-Feb-25 09:05 AM] laaxus#0000

[03-Feb-25 09:05 AM] laaxus#0000

[03-Feb-25 09:06 AM] laaxus#0000
at max price - 1, he would have earned 1


[03-Feb-25 09:06 AM] laaxus#0000
but at max price


[03-Feb-25 09:06 AM] laaxus#0000

[03-Feb-25 09:06 AM] laaxus#0000

[03-Feb-25 09:06 AM] laaxus#0000

[03-Feb-25 09:14 AM] laaxus#0000

[03-Feb-25 09:14 AM] laaxus#0000

[03-Feb-25 09:25 AM] random_di5cord_user#0000
Imagine you are buying a bag of cookies via this mechanism.

You should bid what you think the cookies are worth.  If you think they are worth $5 to you, you bid that.  In this case, you pay at most $5 and get a bag of cookies, if you pay less, you are explicitly happy ($5 worth of cookies for only $4!).  If you don't win the auction, you still have your $5 and are no worse off.  In particular, you are not unhappy because you didn't pay $8 for cookies that only give you $5 of enjoyment.


[03-Feb-25 09:28 AM] realharvey#0000
First come first serve is happening in a lot of scenarios in the world. It's unfair yes, but a necessary evil.

When you go to a supermarket and want to buy something at a discount it's possible that someone else bought it first.

[05-Feb-25 12:08 AM] evov#0000
Copy from Galactic deals on the UFO discord, how I'm handling the sales of 5k5k ships for the moment -
.e. 5k5k Ships.

At the moment, I know there's a lot of people wanting to buy them. I've had my first HCB roll off the lines. My plans (at the moment) - 

First one, I'll make for myself. I don't plan on selling ships that I don't also use.

Next one is due to be ready in about 3 days. In the long term, I intend to sell them for 11mil per ship. In the short term, while demand greatly exceeds the capacity to supply a more dynamic pricing structure is needed.

First ship for sale will be available for 15mil AIC. If it sells before I produce the next one, price for the next one goes up by 1mil. If it doesn't sell, price goes down by 1mil. The floor price will be 11mil (if I end up holding 5 full ships in stock)

They're new, they're pretty, lots of people want them, I expect this to be a very temporary situation.

Send a message in "EvoV's Solo Shipyards"

{Reactions}

[05-Feb-25 08:14 AM] pagy1234#0000
whats the difference between FRM and HYF? I see a couple people recently switching from FRM to HYF


[05-Feb-25 08:23 AM] random_di5cord_user#0000
They produce slightly different things, FRM depends on planet fertility and HYF does not.  Inputs are different for the same items.  (HYF alyways needs NS)


[05-Feb-25 08:24 AM] pagy1234#0000
ahh, so HYF can be made anywhere im assuming?


[05-Feb-25 08:24 AM] pagy1234#0000
but probably more expensive


[05-Feb-25 08:24 AM] random_di5cord_user#0000
I believe so.  Still benefits from agriculture COGC


[05-Feb-25 08:24 AM] pagy1234#0000
thats pretty nice


[05-Feb-25 08:28 AM] random_di5cord_user#0000
But, for example, you can't grow CAF on a FRM or HER in a HYF.


[05-Feb-25 08:28 AM] laaxus#0000
HYF is simply a different building


[05-Feb-25 08:28 AM] laaxus#0000
use BUI commands


[05-Feb-25 08:33 AM] pagy1234#0000
oh yeah i see


[05-Feb-25 08:34 AM] pagy1234#0000
more expensive and more expensive to operate but makes some different stuff


[05-Feb-25 08:34 AM] pagy1234#0000
much smaller recipe choice though


[05-Feb-25 08:35 AM] random_di5cord_user#0000
less area consumed too, but needs settlers


[05-Feb-25 08:35 AM] pagy1234#0000
yeah


[05-Feb-25 08:35 AM] pagy1234#0000
prolly wont get any for some time


[05-Feb-25 09:04 AM] magican1980#0000
yes, it will take time for the change for HYF üôÇ - FRM produce with a little Water, HYF take more Water and Nutrient Solution (NS) to make the same in less time - HYF cost more (because more building mats) and you need to fullfill the needs of settlers üôÇ


[05-Feb-25 09:05 AM] magican1980#0000
with HYF = 20 Water + 2 NS = 12 MAI in 19hours 12 min (without boni), with FRM = 4 Water = 12 MAI in 33 hours


[05-Feb-25 09:08 AM] magican1980#0000
for other products you invest massiv more water and NS to get the items faster. on the other side you can run more Food Processor to make Rations


[05-Feb-25 09:09 AM] magican1980#0000
if you want to simulate somethink like this - I recommend to look for the prunplaner tool üôÇ one example for a HYF for Carbon-INC setup


[05-Feb-25 09:09 AM] magican1980#0000

[08-Feb-25 10:38 AM] razenpok#0000
Expenses: cost of input goods and consumables
Revenue: cost of output goods
Repairs: cost of materials for repairs


[08-Feb-25 10:38 AM] pagy1234#0000
yeah, but the cost values are massively higher than what I currently spend on consumables and stuff


[08-Feb-25 10:39 AM] razenpok#0000
The cost of any material as calculated as a weighted average over all trades of all CXs over the last 7d


[08-Feb-25 10:40 AM] razenpok#0000
It doesn't know what you actually spend on the resources


[08-Feb-25 10:40 AM] razenpok#0000
Or how much do you sell them for


[08-Feb-25 10:40 AM] pagy1234#0000
ahh, maybe thats why


[08-Feb-25 10:40 AM] razenpok#0000
Yeah, it's a "if you would rely solely on CX, this is what numbers are"


[08-Feb-25 10:40 AM] razenpok#0000
"on average"

[09-Feb-25 01:34 PM] tanda#0000
I see you've gotten a lot of responses about this already, but I wanted to explain my line of thought.
I do construction, so I see decentish planets close by and I wonder why they shouldn't be another construction planet. Construction takes up a lot of permits, but I can supply more than one BFAB base with one metallurgy planet. 
There's no point of focusing a system on metallurgy. You put your metallurgy COGCs either on the planet with the metal deposit you want to take advantage of or very close by.
We are spoiled for choice for TIO deposits already in ANT. The one on 759j is less than 50% of galactic maximum, while we have 4 nearbyish that are over 65%.
That and metallurgy planets aren't very profitable right now

what's the range of the poulation review?


[13-Feb-25 01:55 AM] vanarazor#0000
is it by 100's?


[13-Feb-25 01:56 AM] vanarazor#0000
for example, as of right now, my workforce is 200 but I 'd required 240 , if I build some habitation, would that potentially give me 40 , 100 ? pop for the next pop review?  what would be the optimised way to grow population ?


[13-Feb-25 01:59 AM] vanarazor#0000
from what I gather from prplanner the HB1 defines my pop growth taking in account job opportunity


[13-Feb-25 02:00 AM] pxlfox.#0000
the HB1 provides space for workers


[13-Feb-25 02:02 AM] pxlfox.#0000
"required" is what you need to full all jobs, "current" is the amount you currently have employed and "capacity" is the space you have. Capacity is defined by the habitats you build (e.g. HB1). You can't have more popultation then capacity, so you should always have build at least as much capacity as required.

{Attachments}
https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/1183249178156089374/1339506907571945522/image.png?ex=68147c05&is=68132a85&hm=411b44636760917c90e63d22a2ce54e64c9e20c9ca53375a46e99c8393f8d386&


[13-Feb-25 02:02 AM] pxlfox.#0000
pop growth is defined by the planets condition


[13-Feb-25 02:02 AM] pxlfox.#0000
which are monitored and regulated by the planets government


[13-Feb-25 02:03 AM] pxlfox.#0000
normally, on basically all developed planets (which Phobos is), you will get your pioneers filled with the next population report (POPR), which is once a week.


[13-Feb-25 02:04 AM] vanarazor#0000
interesting


[13-Feb-25 02:05 AM] pxlfox.#0000
to check the POPR of your planet, use `POPR <planet-code>` (e.g. `POPR ZV-759c`)


[13-Feb-25 02:06 AM] pxlfox.#0000
you get the timestamp of the last report and can anticipate by that when the next one will be

{Attachments}
https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/1183249178156089374/1339507967854120981/image.png?ex=68147d02&is=68132b82&hm=9af447833af5fb0889a1c8d101997ee8845a4b25b02a94701af21a58542a48f1&


[13-Feb-25 02:06 AM] pxlfox.#0000
(again, every 7 days)


[13-Feb-25 02:07 AM] vanarazor#0000

{Attachments}
https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/1183249178156089374/1339508195185397842/image.png?ex=68147d38&is=68132bb8&hm=2481be3a1686e5e4f89501d05e13eb3156c1e3d0f64c481a3c7b869f70297988&


[13-Feb-25 02:07 AM] pxlfox.#0000
so if your base requires more population and you have the capacity for it, you will get them filled in roughly 6 days


[13-Feb-25 02:08 AM] vanarazor#0000

[13-Feb-25 02:10 AM] jcheung#0000
couple points about this. 'open jobs' and 'unemployment' are slightly inaccurate, those are the values from before POPR. you need to modify them (the one not at 0) by the 'change'

[13-Feb-25 02:12 AM] vanarazor#0000
how do you get that number ?


[13-Feb-25 02:12 AM] pxlfox.#0000
pioneers and settlers will most like just fill up. Every other higher pop tier might need intervention by the government to get them filled


[13-Feb-25 02:12 AM] vanarazor#0000
scientifics were 9909 change was 143


[13-Feb-25 02:13 AM] jcheung#0000
as far as unemployment, you can figure out roughly how many are available for you to use by just multiplying the pop count by the unemployment number-doesn't really matter so much on this planet, but does for smaller worlds; IE there's 10k free pioneers available right now (or rather, at next POPR, there's a smaller amount available for instant hire)


[13-Feb-25 02:13 AM] jcheung#0000
open jobs 1424 - change 143 = actual open 1281

if you do round trip every 5 days you need to compare :
- DW : Profit / Base + 5 days of consummables + 5 days of H2O
- MEA : Profit / Base + days of consummables + 5 days of fim + 5 days of MTP

And FIM MTP are very expensive

MEA might have a higher roi, just do the math
Just don't believe it has a higher return on investment just because it has sa higher profit

this is the setting I recommend to every player starting


[18-Feb-25 03:07 AM] laaxus#0000

[20-Feb-25 01:40 AM] pxlfox.#0000
I have a sheet to calculate the "ideal" metal prices


[20-Feb-25 01:41 AM] pxlfox.#0000
it bascially tries to provide 50k profit for a EXT base - that's the ore price, and then achieve 50k profit for the corresponding SME base


[20-Feb-25 01:41 AM] pxlfox.#0000
the "ideal" ALO price would be around 107 - which is half of what the market currently offers. Lowering the "ideal" AL price down to 760


[20-Feb-25 01:43 AM] pxlfox.#0000
so, it's currently mandatory to produce your own ALO for AL, but the market prices is more or less fine, I guess

[23-Feb-25 05:17 AM] evov#0000
I play the steam version of the game without any extensions/addons/fio support etc.

I get CX price data from the prices csv that can be imported into a spreadsheet.
I get warehouse data by copy/pasting into a sheet.
Some things like building costs and production formulas are manually entered.
Everything else is basically just manipulating data in a spreadsheet to get the information I'm interested in.


[23-Feb-25 05:21 AM] evov#0000
I think the important thing is really just working out what questions are worth answering. What level of precision / detail makes a meaningful impact.


[23-Feb-25 05:30 AM] potaterror#0000

[28-Feb-25 11:08 AM] manhim#0000
I just add ?cache=1 at the end of it and increment the number each times it happens


[28-Feb-25 11:08 AM] manhim#0000
Google will cache the response for 1 hour otherwise and won't retry even if it failed

Unless I misunderstand their use, I'm actually surprised that action packages haven't drawn developer backlash due to the APEX guidelines (https://prosperousuniverse.com/account/guidelines).  But then, so are many of the tools that they seem to be fine with (e.g. FIO), so what do I know....

> Do not use external tools for the automatic retrieval of data from the game world *or to automate actions in the game world*.

[Most of the rest of Refined PrUN doesn't seem to necessarily run afoul of this though]

[03-Mar-25 06:15 AM] pxlfox.#0000
@razenpok could probably explain in detail how it works, but as far as I understand it, it simulates the player doing those stuff - so it clicks the game UI, inputs the amount you want to buy, and creates and order. 
The guidelines are probably referring to bots or hijacking game-endpoints to automate tasks without player interaction. 
The rPrun actions are still player activated


[03-Mar-25 08:46 AM] jcheung#0000
It moves the button that requires your interaction to send server contact, so there's no automation

[04-Mar-25 01:25 PM] razenpok#0000
The bug under the hood is: prun always tries to interact with the "amount" as if it is a string, but it starts out as a number and only becomes a string if it was edited

Amazing.

[08-Mar-25 12:27 PM] jcheung#0000
yes, and that's the problem. greater mass means you have to overcome greater inertia to get it moving in the direction you want it to go

yeah, making there be only planetary experts kinda ruins the point of it, then It could just pass me my 28% boost right from the start since Im going to have it in a month anyways


[11-Mar-25 04:35 AM] evov#0000
The problem with more tiers of experts is that it raises the barrier of entry for people to be competitive.

Higher levels of specialization also sounds like a great idea. . . . until the market runs out of something that people need. There's already a long enough lead time on the market / global production shifting to compensate. Higher levels of specialization tends to discourage people from switching production to meet unmet demands that aren't already in their lane.


[11-Mar-25 04:47 AM] pagy1234#0000
maybe something small would be enough to compensate players who are forced to use less optimal planets to stay in their production lane. maybe 5-10% after 2000 effective hours?


[11-Mar-25 04:47 AM] pagy1234#0000
5th expert is ~950 hours iirc, so 2000 wouldnt be a huge amount with 2+ bases


[11-Mar-25 04:57 AM] evov#0000
I think in general, planetary conditions ( build/repair costs due to hot/cold/high pressure etc ) have too big of an impact. I think it would be a better / more interesting game if there was more incentive to spread out and colonize more planets rather than dog pile onto already popular ones until they're full.


[11-Mar-25 05:03 AM] pagy1234#0000
yeah absolutely, deimos is a perfect example


[11-Mar-25 05:03 AM] pagy1234#0000
a billion people sit on that planet when there are comletely empty planets 1 jump away


[11-Mar-25 05:37 AM] evov#0000
There's a few contributing factors to it, but I think the relative cost of the planetary conditions is probably the single biggest one. Ability to control / get a return from developing planets is the other thing that keeps people clustered on the main planets rather than spreading out.


[11-Mar-25 05:38 AM] laaxus#0000

[15-Mar-25 06:02 PM] evov#0000
My experience has been that fuel costs usually far far exceed repair costs. So it makes sense to optimize for fuel usage. Which means keeping the weight of the ship down. It's also the case that... while the gucci ships require repairs a lot less often... when they do need repairs it's a hell of a lot more expensive if you're not making your own specialized parts.

I know lowstrife has been trying to make an effort to have those parts more available on the CX via consistent buy orders, but they may not always be available.

[15-Mar-25 06:32 PM] evov#0000
For me, when I was comparing the FTL Engines (QCR/HPR/HYP) I found very few use cases where the HPR/HYP were better. The longest flights I regularly do would be ANT -> MOR. Making the trip in 2days, vs 1day 12 hours makes no difference if I'm not online at the time when it arrives. In order to reach the next "availability break point" - I'd need to dial up the reactors... and it would 4x the fuel cost for the flight.


[15-Mar-25 06:35 PM] sidepipe#0000
I'm usually online around 9AM and 9PM most days, so the 12 hour reduction worked out well for me üòÑ


[15-Mar-25 06:36 PM] evov#0000
Or if you're regularly doing flights that would be >2days .. I think the HPR/HYP starts to make more sense imo


[15-Mar-25 06:37 PM] sidepipe#0000

[16-Mar-25 12:27 AM] archielvahr#0000
One small non obvious benefit is that ftl damage is proportional to reactor usage. So you can run it even lower and I find it usually cuts the damage in half at the same duration.


[16-Mar-25 12:27 AM] jcheung#0000
go too low and it doesn't matter


[16-Mar-25 12:28 AM] evov#0000
Yea, I often found at very low reactor usage, there was virtually no difference in speed between the engines. The main benefit of the gucci ones was being able to turn the dial up to 12 when needed to get somewhere fast.


[16-Mar-25 03:55 AM] akyantor#0000
I'm not making quite as much AWH as I used too.. now make balanced quantities of AWH/AHP/SRP/APT. And yes, the market isn't super liquid, but there are more folks dipping in than they used too. My objective is to at least try to provide some availability via the CX, as there's almost none at the moment.

Personally I was wondering how far I can push the A-Fab markets by purchasing them solely from the CX. Another idea I had was pushing into one of the secondary MMs which do not provide IDC levels of profits but instead require an insane amount of precursor bases, but combine this with purchases from the CX. That way a whole bunch of markets could spring to life there.


[17-Mar-25 03:04 AM] evov#0000
Gateways - It is my intention to either sell, or otherwise contribute one complete gate once they become available. I built up the production requirements for this and currently have about 95% of the available parts on hand. Mostly just need to wait for the new "bits" to become available in order to complete this project. If needed (and if there's funding available for it) I've geared up to be able to produce 1 new gate every 100 days, but I don't expect there to be sufficient desire/funding for this to be needed.

Other infrastructure projects - I've developed 2 systems in the ANT region (9 planets) to do high tier production. Actual development cost was about 80million + personal cost/loss for moving bases onto these planets. I'm not expecting a return on this investment any time soon. The intent is to make it a high tier industrial hub that's within 1 day's flight from ANT cx and HRT cx. It will also be the location for a future gateway point. In some cases I offer to fill in a type of MM role for bases on these planets, buying things at fixed prices on planet. 

For reference - the planets / cogc's and relevant pops. If anyone is interested in joining any of these planets, hit me up.

[17-Mar-25 04:54 AM] evov#0000
I already make AIR LOG and all the Capacitor types. I haven't checked recently, but I believe they're worth more for their productive value than their MM value.

r.e. Gate cost - no idea. It's hard to know for sure until the new resources become available I think people are estimating between 300 and 350mil. A good % of the parts for the gate are available in high enough volume on the CX, so whatever CX prices are makes sense for those parts. However, there's a few parts that new production needs to be spun up in order to meet demand for gates, I think once people start building gates we'll find out what those bits are worth. I haven't checked these prices recently, but as a guide for some of the ... less available parts ->

[17-Mar-25 05:27 AM] pagy1234#0000

[17-Mar-25 05:28 AM] taiyibureau#0000

[17-Mar-25 05:28 AM] taiyibureau#0000

[17-Mar-25 05:29 AM] taiyibureau#0000

[17-Mar-25 05:31 AM] pagy1234#0000
Alr, i guess we gotta wait for that info maybe


[17-Mar-25 05:39 AM] evov#0000
I suspect - that the gates that connect the 4 main CX's ... MIGHT be able to pay for themselves eventually... but that's still unclear to me. For the most part I think they're a prestige item. At this stage, when it comes to Cost per item to transport - slow steaming 5k5k ships seems like it will remain the most cost efficient way to transport items between CX's.

4 gates needed to connect ANT -> BEN for example. Rough cost - 1.2 -> 1.5 billion. That's like 120x 5k5k ships you could build for that cost. ( 480 ships for the cost of the full network connecting all the 4 main CX's in a loop of gates ). I'd be very very surprised if the speed difference from using gates  has any hope of increasing volume of shipped goods or reducing cost of shipping them when compared to a 5k5k ship on low fuel settings.

If the objective is to build cool new stuff -> Gates.
If the objective is efficient transfer of large amount of goods -> 5k5k Ships.

[19-Mar-25 04:10 AM] evov#0000
Ever since there was people talking about ideas of warfare and regional conflict in the game, it got me thinking about various things. While I'm not sure what regional conflict in a game like this would even look like, it did lead me to consider a few questions related to it.

1. What factors (that can be influenced by players) can make a region "good".
2. What factors (that can be influenced by players) can make a region "bad".

I think these two questions are at the core of any potential conflict... how do we protect the stuff we want/need  -  how do we negatively impact the stuff our enemies want/need.

I think (and maybe I'm wrong) that the foundational block in the wants/needs of a region is reliable access to consumables and repair materials. I think virtually all economic or productive activity is downstream from this. When you're trying to build a new base or resupply / repair an existing one.... missing even one of the required pieces feels like an unacceptable catastrophe.

If I want to help ensure the prosperity of the ANT region, I think securing reliable access to consumes and repair materials is priority number 1.


[19-Mar-25 04:14 AM] evov#0000
Right now, for example, there's 2237 FIM available on the BEN CX. If I was running ANY bases that employ engineers out of that region, I'd be getting very nervous right about now.

The ANT CX by comparison, has over 17k FIM available right now (in part due to the 10k I just put up there). So people should feel much more comfortable and confident about setting up production in this region if they have reliable access to the things they'll need.

[19-Mar-25 08:17 PM] evov#0000
It doesn't benefit other people producing and trying to sell the item.

It is interesting that people seem to think lowering prices is intrinsically better. It's almost as though the natural state is to view themselves as a producer, and all other players as consumers. Like they're making some sort of noble sacrifice to provide cheap goods to others, when it's equally true that the same action is undercutting other producers and trying to drive them out of business.

[22-Mar-25 08:12 PM] jab.sh#0000
I'm back with a prunplanner question üòÑ how do I calculate the weekly cost to _run this base_ (per week)? it's just a RIG base so if we assume the only cost is workforce + degradation, is it:
`115.61*4.9*7` (4.9 is 1/20.41%)
or `(118+91.52)*7`?
or is it just `(58,310.00-38,483.55)*7`

{Attachments}
https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/1183249178156089374/1353174579731890208/screenshot_20250322190822.png?ex=6814c4c8&is=68137348&hm=8762ea7edd50483a0776c92e64ecf3902ec9093cd6f3f1bc6169d01164c1e9b3&
https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/1183249178156089374/1353174579975028776/screenshot_20250322191205.png?ex=6814c4c8&is=68137348&hm=9c434450411119153ec3edf5a651dd6074d61af83d927d7df4a98baa4426939b&


[22-Mar-25 08:23 PM] sidepipe#0000
I think `115.61 x 4.9 x 7` per RIG is correct


[22-Mar-25 08:26 PM] sidepipe#0000
and I believe that should match 58,310.00 - 38,483.55 * 7


[22-Mar-25 08:26 PM] sidepipe#0000
(i.e. you have 35 RIGs on this base, correct?)


[22-Mar-25 08:26 PM] jab.sh#0000
ah, per rig? interesting


[22-Mar-25 08:26 PM] jab.sh#0000
that makes sense


[22-Mar-25 08:27 PM] sidepipe#0000
Yeah, the COGM panel shows things per building / item (depending on where you look), and then the panel on the right is for the entire base


[22-Mar-25 08:28 PM] sidepipe#0000
cause `115.61 x 4.9 x 7 x 35 = (58310 - 38483.55) x 7`

{Reactions}
üëç 

[22-Mar-25 08:29 PM] jab.sh#0000
excellent thank you

[23-Mar-25 04:58 PM] vanarazor#0000
in the construction planner you can select how many building are already built and how many you would like to build depending on that difference you ''ll get the weight and volume ratio of you construction order.

switching your base configuration does not update your construction planner if you did not save + refreshed the page, it will simply highlight a different set of building built or not and left to build or not .. if it makes any sense.

I 've made mistakes multiples times because of that. I'd would suggest you have a look at your construction planner summary.

[23-Mar-25 10:04 PM] evov#0000
Just keep in mind how those numbers are calculated. If I buy a 100k car... give it a paint job and sell it for 110k ... that report will show as having produced a 110k product. It ignores the input costs. So it's not a perfect reflection of profitability.... just the value of goods that come off the line.


[23-Mar-25 10:05 PM] sidepipe#0000
Don‚Äôt I know it. BWS is one of the most ‚Äúprofitable‚Äù things I make and it all sits in warehouses at the CXs ü•≤


[23-Mar-25 10:06 PM] evov#0000
So that chart will disproportionately favor high end production... where you're taking expensive stuff, combining it to make something slightly more expensive. A lot of that happens when building ships from the ground up.

[24-Mar-25 08:02 AM] evov#0000
For anyone who's a bit lost about the MM discussions on the main prun discord - this the best real world analogy I can come up with to try to explain (at least 1 side of the argument)



IDC's are like.... if the Government decided it would create a new position...  "empathy inspectors"... and paid them double the average wage for the area. Virtually unlimited open positions, but you need to have completed a degree and also obtained a certificate in empathy studies. The job would be to walk around town and point out every time someone is a jerk. Fundamentally a really really easy job, anyone can do it, you just gotta spend the time/money to get your empathy studies certificate.

That's what IDC's are, easy +high paying gov jobs.


Then, people point out this is silly. Why is the gov paying super high salaries to these people who aren't really providing anything useful to the economy?

"Oh - we need to keep paying them heaps of money..... it helps to fight off deflation"

This has been the IDC argument for at least the last 18months.


Today ->   Hey, gov... maybe instead of paying heaps of money for something really easy that no-one needs, maybe we could spend it on more difficult things that have further reaching impact to the economy, like parks or busses or upgraded water pipes? 

Tomorrow -> Insert empathy inspectors crying about how it's not fair that they should get a pay cut, and how the gov paying them heaps above average wages is actually a good thing for the economy. And, omg what about the lecturers at the local college that are doing the classes that give out the empathy certificates. Pay cuts for empathy inspectors will ruin the economy!!!

{Reactions}
üëç (3)

[24-Mar-25 08:08 AM] evov#0000

I just like the higher-tier MMs more because each of them requires more direct inputs, which need bases themselves, and those bases need inputs etc etc.

[24-Mar-25 09:45 AM] pxlfox.#0000
I get the ‚Äúemotional‚Äù complain from people, that IDC makes lots of money from basically doing nothing (tho that money is eventually flowing back into the economy, sooo).

But if I get that right, the global economy is basically losing money (the total sum of available value) by degradation, non-current assets, people leaving the game and materials sold to MM.
This is counter acted by MMs selling stuff, basically creating money out of thin air. This can be done by any MM, tho IDC is just the one with the highest profit.


[24-Mar-25 09:46 AM] pxlfox.#0000
So in other words, we need means of injecting value into the system, which is currently mainly managed by MM - and in a bigger scale, IDC mining


[24-Mar-25 09:47 AM] pxlfox.#0000
Otherwise the system would bleed out and people wouldn‚Äôt be able to trade anymore


[24-Mar-25 09:49 AM] realharvey#0000
IDC Bases also create more FAB-Demand for repairs and High tier consumables. So they are helping with the higher tier economy


[24-Mar-25 09:52 AM] pxlfox.#0000
But I did get that right, didn‚Äôt I? Putting the emotional part of the discussion aside, IDC bases are currently fulfilling a crucial role to ensure this economy is going to grow, aren‚Äôt they? They are not the only nor best means thinkable, but as of rn required or at least beneficial.


[24-Mar-25 09:54 AM] pxlfox.#0000
Because everything else (trading between players) is only distributing value around, but not actually creating new.


[24-Mar-25 09:54 AM] pxlfox.#0000
You just interchange more volume of value with less, higher density of value


[24-Mar-25 09:55 AM] pxlfox.#0000
(e.g. 10 CUO -> 3 CU)


[24-Mar-25 09:58 AM] sidepipe#0000
Really, money only ‚Äòleaves‚Äô the system through people quitting and MMs. Degradation / non-current assets just hand the money to someone else. Money doesn‚Äôt disappear when you repair your base because you paid someone else for it


[24-Mar-25 09:59 AM] pxlfox.#0000
But the building itself loses value, doesn‚Äôt it?


[24-Mar-25 09:59 AM] sidepipe#0000

[03-Apr-25 05:09 AM] evov#0000
Depends how you define profits. You might be looking at how pricing affects supply demand purely through the lens of production / cost of production.

For me.... "high" prices aren't as much in relation to the cost of production ( it does play a part, but a relatively small part in a lot of cases )... but relative to what I expect the future price to be, and what I might have bought my existing stock at.

[03-Apr-25 07:40 AM] magican1980#0000
on all products without market makers, the price moves on demand/supply - On the other side you have the seller - has he the time to wait or change prices regularly to sell their items - for example Rations - @Benten If you sell at 165 (your fist item is sold after 60k units are sold) @Antares your are the first to take the buy (no open sell-order at 165)


[03-Apr-25 07:41 AM] magican1980#0000
in the market are not only producers, who sell their item, but also Traders, who are set buy-orders and sell at the same station at higher prices ... its feels like stocktrading and you must have the cashreserves to do this


[03-Apr-25 07:45 AM] magican1980#0000
on other example is - I produce about 971 carbon daily, about 6.800 units per week -> if I would double the production, the prices would drop down, because their is to much influx to the market. Also at my CX's there a lot of active traders üôÇ

restrict access to _privileged_ roles and channels (think admin roles/channels)
hide channels but anyone can add/remove the roles at will (this can be done with a bot or server onboarding)

[05-Apr-25 03:00 AM] pxlfox.#0000
Regards the discussion in #agp-operations - Everything produced by people to be used internally or traded privately (and therefore not reaching the market) is ultimately still relieving the market, so I think for a market analysis tool, we can ignore that


[05-Apr-25 03:01 AM] pxlfox.#0000
For my own tool, I excluded all ask and bid orders from the book, which are more then double the current prices, to get a better feeling of actual demand and supply, since some people park there mats there


[05-Apr-25 03:03 AM] pxlfox.#0000
And I added the traded amount as demand, tho I‚Äôm not quite sure, if that‚Äôs the right way.

[05-Apr-25 04:55 AM] pxlfox.#0000
- IMPORTDATA("https://rest.fnar.net/csv/cxpc/EPO.AI")
- Filter by 'Interval'=DAY_ONE and 'TimeEpocheMs' in your timeframe and sum the 'Traded' values

https://doc.fnar.net/#/csv/get_csv_cxpc__Ticker_


[05-Apr-25 05:12 AM] pxlfox.#0000
You don't need no python do to so


[05-Apr-25 05:13 AM] pxlfox.#0000

[05-Apr-25 05:22 AM] pxlfox.#0000

[05-Apr-25 12:04 PM] megamint#0000
How do I get a third ship?


[05-Apr-25 12:06 PM] tanda#0000
You need PRO to build and operate a third ship, but what you do is buy all the parts from someone, bring them to a shipyard (for us that's generally going to be Hephaestus), build the blueprint for the ship you're making in  BLU, create a shipyard project to build the ship, then add the parts to the project and start it


[05-Apr-25 12:06 PM] tanda#0000
It'll take 24 hours or so to build the ship from that point


[05-Apr-25 12:08 PM] megamint#0000
Thank you


[05-Apr-25 12:13 PM] tanda#0000
Given your stage of the game, though: You'll want to upgrade your ships first, ADI has a PSK project that handles both loans and upgrade kits for new players


[05-Apr-25 12:13 PM] megamint#0000
Interesting. I'll give it some thought and might come back in a couple days.


[05-Apr-25 12:14 PM] megamint#0000
What are the benefits to upgrading a ship?


[05-Apr-25 12:14 PM] igfloz#0000
#psk-information


[05-Apr-25 12:14 PM] tanda#0000
no rush, you'll probably start needing to upgrade ships around your 3rd or 4th base anyway


[05-Apr-25 12:14 PM] tanda#0000
Upgraded ships is pretty much just swapping out the cargo hold


[05-Apr-25 12:14 PM] igfloz#0000
You basically upgrade your ship form a starter ship into a WCB

[05-Apr-25 01:36 PM] tanda#0000
If your production lines are all empty, ofc it's going to fill with the first order you put in. If you care that much about being balanced even right now, just fill your production lines first, then fill your queues with recurring orders

[05-Apr-25 09:27 PM] evov#0000
I would encourage you to look into the productivity hit you take when buildings start to degrade. Weigh that loss in productivity against the cost savings of using long duration repair cycles.


[05-Apr-25 09:28 PM] vanarazor#0000
theses numbers come from prplan repairs value rate


[05-Apr-25 09:28 PM] vanarazor#0000

[05-Apr-25 09:30 PM] vanarazor#0000

[05-Apr-25 09:34 PM] evov#0000
Example - Buildings at 56 days since last repair.
Buildings at 97% condition. Translates into a 4% loss in productivity.

{Attachments}
https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/1183249178156089374/1358268471506505748/image.png?ex=6814d7d7&is=68138657&hm=2d3df343b8c8e23576c6f819a791a978df94ec71ebdbc3e915035aa7afb8d41a&


[05-Apr-25 09:37 PM] evov#0000
The condition degredation is non-linear. As time since last repair increases.. building condition/performance decreases at a faster rate.


[05-Apr-25 09:38 PM] vanarazor#0000

{Attachments}
https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/1183249178156089374/1358269544522842192/image.png?ex=6814d8d6&is=68138756&hm=3534b41c019a51d9372a46a921932330cb96d3740f5328eb08dcc416c0064caa&


[05-Apr-25 09:39 PM] vanarazor#0000

[05-Apr-25 09:39 PM] vanarazor#0000

{Attachments}
https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/1183249178156089374/1358269907002720276/image.png?ex=6814d92d&is=681387ad&hm=92a822523e4172ed166228c13a0a5ad7445b129343d6b1dae9d1b2d12a6b0e59&


[05-Apr-25 09:40 PM] evov#0000
Population efficiency is low because you require more pop than you have provided.

{Reactions}
üëÜüèΩ 

[05-Apr-25 09:40 PM] evov#0000
Required 720 Pio -  Capacity 700


[05-Apr-25 09:40 PM] vanarazor#0000
now I remmeber üôÇ


[05-Apr-25 09:41 PM] vanarazor#0000
so condition of the building defines directly efficiency


[05-Apr-25 09:41 PM] evov#0000
You will notice that as the time since last repair increases.... the building will degrade faster. Which effectively increases the time per order.


[05-Apr-25 09:41 PM] vanarazor#0000
so you are telling that some repairs could be worth doing even earlier than what prplan is advising


[05-Apr-25 09:42 PM] vanarazor#0000
depending of the value produced by such building


[05-Apr-25 09:42 PM] evov#0000
This time increase effectively means, per order, the cost component for repairs + consumables increase by x%, and the volume of orders decreases by x%.


[05-Apr-25 09:44 PM] vanarazor#0000
in other words in cost as much to produce as less because of the efficiency loss due to %integrity / condition


[05-Apr-25 09:44 PM] evov#0000
Instead of making 100 units per day, you make 96 units per day. Since consumables and repairs accumulate per day, not per order... each order is effectively costing you more.


[05-Apr-25 09:45 PM] evov#0000
At low % degradation... it's not super important... but the degradation ramps up the longer you leave it.

{Reactions}
üëÜüèΩ

[05-Apr-25 09:51 PM] evov#0000

[05-Apr-25 11:03 PM] manhim#0000
Yup. Like something that I see is that AI has no real context of the whole code base, so sometimes it tries to implement/use new access controls systems (or an alternate one that works on the system, but is not used) that don't talk with the one that should be used and it leads to security gaps.

It's technically not wrong code, but there's still a long way to go before it's viable in the hands of anyone without the proper expertise.

[06-Apr-25 10:15 AM] pxlfox.#0000
Yes, buildings will degrade over time regardless, if they produce something or not


[06-Apr-25 10:16 AM] pxlfox.#0000
the same goes for workers - they will consume materials regardless if they produce something


[06-Apr-25 10:16 AM] pxlfox.#0000
so a base not producing is basically loosing money


[06-Apr-25 10:16 AM] igfloz#0000

{Embed}

Efficiency factors :: Prosperous Universe Handbook
General information Each Production Line operates at a certain efficiency when active. Efficiency dictates how long a production order takes to finish: lower efficiency results in longer production times, higher efficiency shortens them. A Production Line‚Äôs current efficiency can be looked up in its Production queue buffer (PRODQ):
Building co...

Two things.
1) if there isn't a MM capping the price upwards, someone simply just buys through your ask, and buys high enough that nobody sells into your bid anymore
2) someone dumps a stockpile or brings to market production they weren't listing before, causing a general price decrease

how are ties in elections resolved?


[08-Apr-25 01:15 PM] sidepipe#0000
For two players who have the same # of votes, the person who ran first gets the seat. That person will also get listed above everyone else (with the same # of votes) in the list of candidates

[08-Apr-25 07:41 PM] optimizedfunction#0000
column 1 is origin
2 is destination
3 is mat
4 is origin price /u
5 is probably number of units at price in 4
6 is dest price /u
7 is probably number of units at price in 6

[14-Apr-25 02:15 PM] razenpok#0000
So
Yes, rprun is written in Vue, but fun fact: in the beginning, I was developing it in React. I have quite some experience in Vue (one of the developers of Antimatter Dimensions, https://store.steampowered.com/app/1399720/Antimatter_Dimensions/), but I wanted to try something new, so I picked React because the PrUn itself is a React app. Idk, it was a weak point, but I went with it. After a month, I figured out that either I was doing something wrong with React, or React itself was giving me shit, because the code was getting more and more complex without much reason. So, I switched to Vue, and many things got simpler. In the current state, refined prun is not a pure Vue app but rather a soup of direct DOM manipulations via mini-features (like item icons) and a multitude of Vue mini-apps (mainly XIT commands). It won't give you a good example of how Vue apps should be made if you are looking for that.

{Embed}
https://store.steampowered.com/app/1399720/Antimatter_Dimensions/),
Antimatter Dimensions
Antimatter Dimensions is a highly unfolding Idle Incremental game with multiple layers of unlocks, prestige, and achievements\. The basic goal is to reach Infinity and receive an Infinity point, which can be spent on various upgrades to increase your overall production\. After Infinity the game has just begun, as there are much, much more to discov‚Ä¶
https://images-ext-1.discordapp.net/external/8ExqVH_bR2yRDyNUphskTu5HOpuwYZNoG35pAI7NE2A/%3Ft%3D1671837279/https/shared.akamai.steamstatic.com/store_item_assets/steam/apps/1399720/header.jpg

{Reactions}
üëçüèΩ ‚ù§Ô∏è 

[14-Apr-25 02:15 PM] razenpok#0000
Here's the best comparison between Vue and React I've seen so far, and it resonates with my experience with them

{Attachments}
https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/1183249178156089374/1361419693436571779/image.png?ex=681519e4&is=6813c864&hm=ea02bed333eef934d8e5411b93e2e4236240ebf8685cf695f2221d1b3606d02b&

Less than ideal to hear; too bad I wasn't around when you first started it, I could've helped you figure out what the issue you were facing at that time was, no worries though.

[14-Apr-25 02:22 PM] razenpok#0000
Or just ping me in Discord


[14-Apr-25 02:22 PM] harkenn#0000
> Why React doesn't accept an array of strings as a class in jsx???

JSX itself doesn't allow it; and as to why that's the case I've never bothered to look into the various proposals over the years where facebook engineers of the time debated the implementation.

The typical solution is to use the `classnames` package, which adds other rather useful features like conditionally applying classes via in-lined logic.


[14-Apr-25 02:23 PM] harkenn#0000
https://github.com/facebook/react/issues/20050 is the most recent time I found that has links to some of the historical proposals (see bvaughn's response)

{Embed}
https://github.com/facebook/react/issues/20050
Feature Proposal: className can be an array of class names strings ...
Description The current className prop on any JSX element takes only a string, that is supposed to be the class name to add to the corresponding element. This prop expects a string which makes it v...

[16-Apr-25 02:25 PM] archielvahr#0000
My first job was at a school information system company- think student tracking, grades, enrollments, lunch money, all that stuff. I started when there were 40 people at the company, a year and a half later there were 400. 

One of my tickets was the first ticket we ever had a code review for, basically the trial run for the new process. It was a small ticket, something to remove duplicate enrollments (one student enrolled twice in the same grade at a school). Well it got reviewed by my boss and team lead.... got approved... went to the staging server... and bam, it deleted every enrollment that *wasn't* duplicated. 

They had to restore all the staging servers, which apparently was a lot of work... but hey, that's what staging is for üòÑ
