[16-Apr-25 02:28 PM] harkenn#0000
The description says increases output, but is that just in the form of production throughput (reduced production time) or actual output efficiency (25% more output per input)?


[16-Apr-25 02:28 PM] harkenn#0000
I've not gotten the grant or anything yet. I'm still under a basic license, just getting a feel and at least trying to be efficient


[16-Apr-25 02:29 PM] finestone#0000
reduced production time


[16-Apr-25 02:29 PM] archielvahr#0000
More output per unit time, plus more output per unit of workforce consumable (rations and DW). And thus more output per building depreciation. But not more output per input material. But it's a big deal.


[16-Apr-25 02:30 PM] archielvahr#0000
But yeah, like Finest_One said, brand new players often want more variety on their starter planet, so it's fine. Especially on Phobos.

[16-Apr-25 02:36 PM] archielvahr#0000

[16-Apr-25 02:36 PM] archielvahr#0000

[16-Apr-25 02:37 PM] archielvahr#0000
Like I'm gonna extract water, grow crops, build an incinerator for carbon, AND smelt ore.


[16-Apr-25 02:37 PM] archielvahr#0000
"optimal" would be only FRMs or only SMEs or only INCs on each planet. But if you are stuck with only one planet, having 20 of the same building is boring


[16-Apr-25 02:38 PM] archielvahr#0000
And boring is worse than "optimal" for player retention üòÑ


[16-Apr-25 02:38 PM] archielvahr#0000
`COLIQ` is the reset command, it throws out everything and starts fresh.

[16-Apr-25 04:17 PM] pxlfox.#0000
that (+2) indicates over population. Normally you can only setup a base on a planet with available plots. But since Deimos is a starter planet, new players can get there a base even tho the planet is technically full. 
Goes for every starter planet, but Deimos is especially most of the time overcrowded.


[16-Apr-25 04:18 PM] harkenn#0000

[17-Apr-25 10:00 AM] jcheung#0000
You can think of each type of expert having its own xp bar. Each completion of matching industry gives xp. Assigning expert will speed up xp gain for that type, and not affect the others

[18-Apr-25 06:53 AM] tanda#0000

[18-Apr-25 06:54 AM] tanda#0000
HAB is pretty much entirely backroom deals to get what you need, since so few people have UPFs


[18-Apr-25 07:09 AM] evov#0000
There's a few things working against HAB availability.

1. Probably the biggest one is charity. Pop inf is often viewed as a "public good". So when Gov's put out the call asking for materials to upgrade stuff, potential producers often provide them at a discount. In some cases, they sell for less than cost of the input materials. This makes it very very unattractive for people to set up any production with HAB/LU/WOR as the goal. That, coupled with relatively low demand consistency means planning to make these goods is a very bad business.

2. The building that makes them (UPF) also makes command bridges and crew quarters. I think people would be shocked to know the price I'd have to sell HAB/WOR/LU for in order to meet the same profitability margins as I'd make on some of those ship parts.


[18-Apr-25 07:14 AM] tanda#0000
2) I get, but it's shocking to see how many non-ship builders completely dismiss UPFs as a profit stream at all


[18-Apr-25 07:21 AM] evov#0000
Looking at HAB - There's been zero sold on the CX in the past week.
There are - 32 currently available on the CX.
Prices range from 120k to 180k

I would say it very very very meets the definition of a product that is currently over supplied.


[18-Apr-25 07:22 AM] laaxus#0000
yeah but is the price of those hab fair ?


[18-Apr-25 07:22 AM] laaxus#0000
I could put 100 million LTA on the cx, if they're priced 500k AIC/u, no one will buy them and can barely be called "supply"


[18-Apr-25 07:23 AM] evov#0000
The cheapest HAB's are for 120k. I don't know if that's "fair" or not. I know that I wouldn't bother making any if there's zero sales of it.


[18-Apr-25 07:23 AM] laaxus#0000
true enough

start with ~~redacted~~


[22-Apr-25 10:17 AM] jcheung#0000
multiply with
```=let (
endLevel,H7,
startLevel,H6,
FLOOR( endLevel * ( endLevel / 2 ) / 2 ) - FLOOR( startLevel * ( startLevel / 2 ) / 2 ) + if(startLevel = 0, 1, 0)
)```


[22-Apr-25 10:17 AM] jcheung#0000
replace h7 and h6 with current and target levels respectively

[22-Apr-25 11:13 AM] realharvey#0000
Also the efficiency gain by specialized ship blueprints for a specific usecase is pretty negligible


[22-Apr-25 12:34 PM] optimizedfunction#0000
The designs are based on experimentation (using BLU and BTF) 
- QCR and FSE work best in most situations.
- Dont need the seats usually.
- Shields are very expensive so only those who make them or those who have money to throw around use them
- medium or large fuel tanks are just preference. LSL is overkill tho unless its an SF hauler. I run large SF tanks on 2 of my LCBs since they exclusively haul SF.
- LHP because i think very few people make BHP, since LHP is lighter, makes ships go faster, and is cheaper to repair.
- drones are shit compared to the price iirc
- and all the fancy extra stuff (shields, seats, drones) add weight, slowing your ship down. To counter that, people sometimes may consider specialty engines but those would most likely need to be made to order due to the lack of a market for them.

{Reactions}
üëÜ

[24-Apr-25 08:47 AM] jcheung#0000
Look at the shipping demands of each of your bases, then get an average round trip flight time, add 12 hours. Whatever supply period you decide to maintain at each base, if you can sustain that level each time period, you're good.

üåà 

[27-Apr-25 12:19 PM] pxlfox.#0000
Regards population - what am I exactly trying to achieve? 
If there is a shortage, I obviously want to increase migration/education, so that everybody gets there workers.
Also, I want to maintain happiness above 50%, so population level keep steady. 
But if everything is fine, what should I do? Do I need to do anything?


[27-Apr-25 12:19 PM] pxlfox.#0000
And how do I find out, that everything is "fine"?


[27-Apr-25 12:19 PM] jab.sh#0000
I'm a noob too, but from what I understand is you don't want to waste money either, so if pop is fine don't try to raise it


[27-Apr-25 12:21 PM] tanda#0000
1) you're trying to keep a steady population, either steady growth or flat, depending on what your planet needs. (Most planets are growing, so growth makes sense)
2) if everything is fine, you see the absolute minimum pop supply you can get away with and just feed that until things change to "not fine" or "needs growth"


[27-Apr-25 12:22 PM] tanda#0000
3) either Archiel's governing sheet or PRUNplanner's government mode is going to be able to give  you the in depth analysis you need to make judgement calls


[27-Apr-25 12:22 PM] tanda#0000
and given the changes coming on the 5th to POP consumption, I recommend Archiel's sheet. Prunplanner has been really slow keeping up to date on any game changes


[27-Apr-25 12:23 PM] pxlfox.#0000
how to decide, if my planet needs growth?


[27-Apr-25 12:24 PM] jab.sh#0000

[27-Apr-25 12:24 PM] pxlfox.#0000

[27-Apr-25 12:24 PM] pxlfox.#0000

[27-Apr-25 12:24 PM] jab.sh#0000

[27-Apr-25 12:25 PM] jab.sh#0000

[27-Apr-25 12:26 PM] pxlfox.#0000
That's obivous - but open jobs only appear in the next POPR _after_ somebody placed down a base. Ideally, you want them filled as fast as possible. Also, ENG and SCI grow really slowly, so it will take some time to get them filled.

[28-Apr-25 01:50 AM] evov#0000
If there are no current jobs for that pop tier, best to leave it at zero. Problem with getting population in a tier that doesn't have any jobs.....   1 worker with zero jobs = 100% unemployment = 0% happiness. Happiness gets averaged out over several weeks. So, as counter intuitive as it may be, if there's zero jobs for engineers, having zero engineers is the best way to quickly fill pop when a new base goes down.

This might not be that easy to manage, you may get some tech's moving up through education anyway.

{Reactions}
üëç 

[28-Apr-25 03:36 AM] razenpok#0000
The main problem (from a dev standpoint) with recurring orders is that they incur CPU and memory costs without any player interaction. For me, it sounds reasonable not to allow non-paying users to create additional running costs.

{Reactions}
VoteYes (3) 

[28-Apr-25 03:59 AM] laaxus#0000
I don't think recuring orders should be that computer intensive tbh


[28-Apr-25 04:02 AM] razenpok#0000
Consider all the involved parts - updating the production line (and possibly other production lines that rely on its outputs), experts, workforce, inventory changes, notifications, FIN updates, probably something else I could not remember


[28-Apr-25 04:04 AM] razenpok#0000
Ah, fees also, that affects the government FIN books


[28-Apr-25 04:05 AM] razenpok#0000
Also updating LEAD database

Banks as an official game mechanic
Banks have been floating around PrUn functionally for a long time now. Lowstrife has offered his loans since before I joined the game. Then there was Shrewdbank. And before Insula vanished, he also ran a sort of bank like organization. Now you have organizations like ADI or BEST that offer new members grants. And you still have Schaitr‚Äôs cheap...

[28-Apr-25 06:24 AM] evov#0000
In theory - loans / banking is a good idea. High permit players have a hard time getting the same rate of return on their capital that low permit players can get. So it makes sense for high permit players to loan capital to low permit players and the profits from a high rate of return get split.

BUT . . . 
1. It's hard to securitize loans in the game. People borrow lots from multiple places, play for a month or two and quit without paying back the loans. So it's a difficult problem to attribute risk.

2. From my perspective - it's just very un-interesting. Having fat stacks of capital sitting around allows me to do things that feel more fun and engaging than simply loaning it out for some low % rate of return.

I think the ANT Central Bank idea sounds cool and interesting in theory, but there's a few major hurdles there that would need to be solved before I'd think about putting AIC towards helping back it.


[28-Apr-25 06:58 AM] pxlfox.#0000
The problem with people loaning out money and just leaving is obviously not solvable, but could be minimised by having a ‚Äúbackground check‚Äù for every application. Tho additional bureaucracy in a game is always a hurdle for borrower and lender. That‚Äôs probably the reason, why lowstrife mostly just accepts contracts send to them.


[28-Apr-25 06:59 AM] pxlfox.#0000
Also, the story of shrewdsun shows how risky it can be to lend out other peoples money. Especially if they expect some fixed ROI


[28-Apr-25 07:01 AM] pxlfox.#0000
By ‚Äúbackground check‚Äù I mean a screenshot of XIT FIN and XIT FINPR, days online and maybe a ‚Äúcredit score‚Äù by already payed loans .

[30-Apr-25 01:08 AM] evov#0000
It's an unfortunate point of the game. High pop planets get pop faster, and there isn't really enough of a downside to it. So the tendency is population around the universe is very clustered around a few large planets. I think it would be a more interesting universe if the population was more spread out. If there were more compelling reasons to move to less populated / more distant planets.

{Reactions}
üíØ (2) 

[30-Apr-25 01:09 AM] pxlfox.#0000
The changes to the pop upkeep should make it easier to accumulate pop, tho the inherit problem of getting to a reasonable pop level stays


[30-Apr-25 01:10 AM] evov#0000
Not for new/small planets. I don't think it'll make a big difference there tbh. The increased education rates will help with larger planets that have a lot of low tier workforce they don't need though.


[30-Apr-25 01:11 AM] pxlfox.#0000
I guess somebody has to be the first one to settle for those distant planets


[30-Apr-25 01:12 AM] pxlfox.#0000
Another problem is the absence of a CX / the long distance to one


[30-Apr-25 01:13 AM] evov#0000
I think the devs have spoken about it in the past. The "intent" was that you'd get better / more resource rich planets as you move away from the CX's. But something about the initial seeding of the universe didn't go as planned.


[30-Apr-25 01:14 AM] pxlfox.#0000
Still - If I look at some resource extraction planets we currently have, you'll need at least a ship full time to export all of it. If they get richer the farther you're away, the more shipping you need.

{Reactions}

[30-Apr-25 11:00 AM] jhyn.#0000
Quick newbie question, is flying with a full tank less efficient than flying with only the fuel you need (like more mass -> more fuel consumed)?


[30-Apr-25 11:01 AM] pagy1234#0000
there is barely a difference


[30-Apr-25 11:02 AM] pagy1234#0000
noticable difference only occurs when you have thousands of tons of stuff


[30-Apr-25 11:03 AM] jhyn.#0000
alrighty, so no need to bother counting how much fuel you need, thanks


[30-Apr-25 11:04 AM] laaxus#0000
actually, you should always try to fly with tank full


[30-Apr-25 11:05 AM] laaxus#0000
because having a ship stranded is quite unpleasant


[30-Apr-25 11:22 AM] realharvey#0000
It also prevents you from: whoops I have no money for fuel


[30-Apr-25 11:39 AM] jcheung#0000
With the starter ship, even full/empty cargo bay isn't enough to matter. The engine is strong enough to be limited by Gs rather than power.


[30-Apr-25 11:40 AM] jcheung#0000
At larger ship scales, a fully loaded ship has so much mass that your fuel tanks won't make a huge differencr


[30-Apr-25 11:41 AM] jcheung#0000
That said, the sliders are based off of how much fuel you have on the tank, so if you want to add a few hours to your travel and save some fuel because you're going to be sleeping


[30-Apr-25 11:41 AM] jcheung#0000
You can put some fuel aside to be able to access a lower range


[30-Apr-25 11:42 AM] jcheung#0000
There's still going to be a minimum you hit eventually, but it's going to be lower than that of a full tank


[30-Apr-25 11:42 AM] jcheung#0000
...hope you understood that
